qas.question: have you finally "snapped" and just did the changes with crying and screaming in the background (this is what will probably happen in my case when i start changing anything)?

answers.text: she's mostly quite appreciative, but it's verbal.
it helps, but it won't save my back nor mental health.
i'll appreciate any support here, i know this post sounds quite cold but i'm really just not myself anymore.
so my mother is terminally ill, and basically fully paralized.
that said, she believes (not hopes, she's 100% sure, at least on the outside) that she'll get better.
she's mostly quite appreciative, but it's verbal.
it helps, but it won't save my back nor mental health.

context: so my mother is terminally ill, and basically fully paralized. i'm her sole caregiver, i'm not counting my 90yo grandma (her mom) because she's helping as much as she can, but obviously in that age she only can do so much. my mother is obviously not happy with the situation, and i understand that completely. to say that facing your own death racing at you every day is hard, is to say nothing.  i'm obviously trying to do my best and give her as much comfort as possible, including emotional and physical help.  that said, she believes (not hopes, she's 100% sure, at least on the outside) that she'll get better. let me be clear - i hope for that too, but i know how the reality looks like and it's not bright. because of this, she doesn't want to agree to anything that could actually help her, including some minor remodeling to our small flat that would help me helping her. it gets ridiculous now, because i start to feel it in my back (i'm a big guy so leaning 100 times a day takes its toll) and still my every suggestion is shit down with "i'll be healthy" or "i have worse than you, take that into consideration", which is true, but it's comparing apples to a train.  i'm getting burned out of empathy towards her. she's mostly quite appreciative, but it's verbal. it helps, but it won't save my back nor mental health. i have quite a lot going on in my life and i try to somewhat keep it from her, but i'm near my limit.  it's half rant, half question. i wanted to ask you, have you been in similar situation? how did you resolved it? have you finally "snapped" and just did the changes with crying and screaming in the background (this is what will probably happen in my case when i start changing anything)? i'll appreciate any support here, i know this post sounds quite cold but i'm really just not myself anymore. :(

qas.question: im just so tired of this whole situation, does anyone have similar stories that they can share?

answers.text: hi everyone, so my dad had a very severe hemorrhage stroke about 2 years ago, and even to this date, his memory is super bad, have left neglect, cannot move his left hand and arm at all, and cant walk, and cant really control his left leg.

im constantly very sad whenever i see him zooming out when i talk to him, and never seem to try to stand up straighter or try to learn to do something to improve.. i hate to see him having to live in long term care for the rest of his life.

ive been seeing him and caring for his every single day since his stroke 2 years ago, but soon i will be going back to school, and its not possible for me to visit and help him exercise or brush his teeth anymore.

context: hi everyone, so my dad had a very severe hemorrhage stroke about 2 years ago, and even to this date, his memory is super bad, have left neglect, cannot move his left hand and arm at all, and cant walk, and cant really control his left leg.  ive been helping him do standing exercises to try to strengthen his left leg, but im getting very frustrated and very tired and do not see any hope whatsoever. im constantly very sad whenever i see him zooming out when i talk to him, and never seem to try to stand up straighter or try to learn to do something to improve.. i hate to see him having to live in long term care for the rest of his life. i regret so much for saving him back then, and i cry myself to sleep every other day after coming home from his place. ive been seeing him and caring for his every single day since his stroke 2 years ago, but soon i will be going back to school, and its not possible for me to visit and help him exercise or brush his teeth anymore.  im just so tired of this whole situation, does anyone have similar stories that they can share?  :(

context: hello, all! i've recently moved my mom into assisted living, which takes a significant load off of my shoulders. however, she recently experienced her first fire drill there, and long story short, the ear shattering noise added extra stress which put her into a fib. we asked if they could give us a heads up before fire drills so she could get out of the building, but it looks like that isn't going to happen. what can we use to block out the noise other than ear plugs? she really doesn't mind if she can hear it, but it's so loud that she'd like to avoid feeling like she is at a club. i'd love your tips. thanks!

qas.question: can you tell who's been in lots of zoom meetings with coworkers recently?

context: i think this headline says it all, but i've been told of late i need to speak more openly about things but when i do people look at me like cockeyed and it yields nothing. if i had kids to be oh blah blah blah. can you tell who's been in lots of zoom meetings with coworkers recently?

qas.question: do you remember a gift or a favor someone did for you that really meant a lot to you or that you actually found useful?

answers.text: the last two years havent been kind to us (covid aside), and this current scare (hes currently in the icu with sepsis shock, but stable) and my poor mom has literally been running on 2-3 hours a sleep/night if shes lucky.
she cannot use bath bombs or other scented bubble bath/luxury soaks.
not a big fan of candles, but coming around.
she also has a westie - her little sidekick.
my step-dad has been living with stage 4 renal cancer for over 10 years.

context: forgive me if this type of post isnt welcomed here, but im at a loss, and i would be so grateful for suggestions for meaningful gifts i could get her...im not nor have ever been a caregiver myself; i dont want to make assumptions for a situation i have never experienced.  my step-dad has been living with stage 4 renal cancer for over 10 years. the last two years havent been kind to us (covid aside), and this current scare (hes currently in the icu with sepsis shock, but stable) and my poor mom has literally been running on 2-3 hours a sleep/night if shes lucky.  when or if youve ever found yourselves in the middle of these horrifying scenarios as a primary caregiver, what type of comfort did you yearn for? do you remember craving anything? do you remember a gift or a favor someone did for you that really meant a lot to you or that you actually found useful?  i know these are kind of odd questions, but like i said before, i just want them to be meaningful and useful by providing even the littlest bit of comfort.  she cannot use bath bombs or other scented bubble bath/luxury soaks. not a big fan of candles, but coming around. she also has a westie - her little sidekick.  thank you so much if youve taken the time to read until the very end, and for allowing me to seek advice from your community. i have so much respect and compassion for the work you do.

qas.question: what do i say??

answers.text: hi, im not sure where to post, really.
my uncle has a mother in law suite and had her move in with him about 10 years ago, which was awesome because they both had plenty of space & did their own thing.
i live out of state & visit 1-2x a year & call weekly.
fast forward to march of this year and she fell a couple of times/is now bedridden with increasing dementia & needs 24hr care.
her staff is amazing, and one lady encouraged me to visit sooner than later in the summer.
so i flew over that weekend and was taken aback by how shes doing.
i asked her workers to let me help them bc im family and god knows my grandma has always helped people in her life.
she is so tired and wants to sleep, but obviously staying clean and dry are essential when shes forced to lie on her back 24/7.
the thing is mom was so clear that she never wanted to be unable to care for herself and once that was confirmed by doctors i had no choice but to honor her wishes.
i have started calling daily, but find myself at a loss for words.
our old conversations fall flat.
i dont know how to pretend like everything is ok anymore.
please let go.
also, to you caregiversi used to do personal care services for adults and kids with dd.
this experience was so eye opening as far as the physical and mental work you all do.
hi, im not sure where to post, really.
sending you all a lot of love.

context: hi, im not sure where to post, really.  my (41f) grandmother is 95 and we have always been very close.  my uncle has a mother in law suite and had her move in with him about 10 years ago, which was awesome because they both had plenty of space & did their own thing.  i live out of state & visit 1-2x a year & call weekly.  always been super independent, but after 90 she started to decline, understandably.  fast forward to march of this year and she fell a couple of times/is now bedridden with increasing dementia & needs 24hr care.  her staff is amazing, and one lady encouraged me to visit sooner than later in the summer.  so i flew over that weekend and was taken aback by how shes doing.  i asked her workers to let me help them bc im family and god knows my grandma has always helped people in her life.  but i cant get the changing adult diapers, especially out of my head.  she is so tired and wants to sleep, but obviously staying clean and dry are essential when shes forced to lie on her back 24/7.  it hurt her and she kept crying out for jesus to help her.  i was right there, and these women were all being as gentle as possible, but shes getting spots on her bottom that are incredibly painful and she has no choice but to lay there and comply all day every day.  it hurts my soul, and i have literally been praying for her to pass so shes not stuck in this miserable life anymore.  i was with my mom (her daughter) when she was removed from life support, and the visit is bringing some of that back.  the thing is mom was so clear that she never wanted to be unable to care for herself and once that was confirmed by doctors i had no choice but to honor her wishes.  my grandma doesnt have that option and it kills me.  i have started calling daily, but find myself at a loss for words.  what do i say??  our old conversations fall flat.  what are you doing/is the weather nice/whats been going on? .  she told me years ago that after our papaw died she made up her mind to stay around for us grandkids.  tonight i asked her how shes feeling and she sounded dejected, half lucid.  you know, i lay here and look at this celing and fan.  i dont know how to pretend like everything is ok anymore.  everybody tries to be cheerful but i want to tell her its ok to let go.  please let go.  sorry this is so long.  im just heartbroken and hate being so awkward now.  also, to you caregiversi used to do personal care services for adults and kids with dd.  this experience was so eye opening as far as the physical and mental work you all do.  sending you all a lot of love.

qas.question: he wants what my husband and i watch (netflix/hulu/sling) but it wants it on his cable  ??

answers.text: he is very out of touch with...everything lol.
so this morning hes frustrated with his cable.
i explain his cable package doesnt provide that.
he doesnt have or want to pay for the dvr function.
i spent an entire hour going over his tv functions.
showing him every possible way he could watch a specific movie or show.
he either has to pay to rent, pay for the dvr function, or wait days in order to get it for free.
so that brought us to the topic of streaming services.
has never even had an email address or cell phone.
he thinks im pulling the wool over his eyes.
he thinks we lie but things are much more complex then he can understand anymore :/
he will only go to doctor or dentist but nowhere else.
he is very out of touch with...everything lol.
so this morning hes frustrated with his cable.
i explain his cable package doesnt provide that.
he doesnt have or want to pay for the dvr function.
showing him every possible way he could watch a specific movie or show.
he either has to pay to rent, pay for the dvr function, or wait days in order to get it for free.
he was so confused.
its like explaining these things to a 2 year old.
the generational gap in our home is so large.

context: backstory: my grandpa is 83. he had a stroke over 30 years ago that left him disabled. since the late 80s hes chosen to be home bound. he hates shopping, crowds, getting in the car etc. he will only go to doctor or dentist but nowhere else. he is very out of touch with...everything lol.  so this morning hes frustrated with his cable. he wants to watch a specific show but he wants the option to pause it for bathroom breaks and fast forward through commercials. i explain his cable package doesnt provide that. he doesnt have or want to pay for the dvr function. i spent an entire hour going over his tv functions. showing him every possible way he could watch a specific movie or show. he either has to pay to rent, pay for the dvr function, or wait days in order to get it for free.  so that brought us to the topic of streaming services. he wants what my husband and i watch (netflix/hulu/sling) but it wants it on his cable  ?? he was so confused. he doesnt understand the internet period. has never even had an email address or cell phone. its like explaining these things to a 2 year old. he just has no grasp on how the world works anymore.  so now hes frustrated. he thinks im pulling the wool over his eyes. he wants me to preform a miracle but its just not possible unless he forks up the money to his cable company. he does this with a lot of things actually. he still thinks the world runs as it did before he had a stroke, when things were a little more simple/cheap.  sigh. its just hard. the generational gap in our home is so large. he thinks we lie but things are much more complex then he can understand anymore :/

she's nuts if she thinks the waiver people will grant us anything close to that.

he will be going home with more needs than before.

that'd be 168 paid hours a week.

does anyone happen to know the reprocussions of a discharge ama (against medical advice)?

context: hello. a very urgent and very bad situation is unfolding at a snf rehab. my father has been in this unit for almost 3 weeks now. he will be going home with more needs than before. he has a medicaid waiver that gives his family member 26 paid hours a week as it stands. the rehab's social worker says that he needs more hours than that in order to be granted a discharge. fair enough. problem is, she is very adamant that 24 hours a day is the only solution. that'd be 168 paid hours a week. she's nuts if she thinks the waiver people will grant us anything close to that. the lady will not come down on that demand though. i know she won't be happy with whatever new hours we secure soon. and my father has been endlessly sitting in there growing very upset. what should i do? does anyone happen to know the reprocussions of a discharge ama (against medical advice)? by the way i don't think my father needs 24 hour care. half that, sure, but not that amount. he knows who he is, is mostly competent, etc. how do i stand up to this lady's death grip on our discharge without risking our waiver, our legal status if he does get hurt unsupervised, etc.? thanks.

qas.question: if you're interested, please see the post below...  do you provide care to a family member with #dementia?

answers.text: it's been a while since we've posted, but we are still looking for participants for our study on dementia caregivers!
we are with the school of nursing at the university of alabama at birmingham, and our goal is to learn more about the daily experiences and stressors of dementia caregivers!
this study is done entirely online, and we also compensate you for your participation.
we invite you to participate and share your day-to-day experiences with us.
this study seeks to enroll family #caregivers to complete daily diaries for a #research study.
we will pay you for your time.
your answers remain anonymous and your experiences can be valuable for us to provide better care for care receivers.

if you're interested in participating, please click this link to see if you are eligible: www.caregivingresearch.org/daily-reflections for more information about who we are, visit our website at: https://www.caregivingresearch.org/
it's been a while since we've posted, but we are still looking for participants for our study on dementia caregivers!
if you would like to share your experiences as a caregiver we'd love to hear from you!

qas.question: wondering if anyone out there might have any suggestions for us?

answers.text: she used to be easy to take care of but because of the closures of her day program, she has been acting out and making life very difficult for us for the past year.

as the future of this pandemic is still up-in-the-air with no definite timeline, and no indication of when her day program or any other supports will open again  we are now considering if it is time to put her in a home.
i feel like we only have 2 basic options and neither suit us well:  1) continue to keep her home.
pro: maybe it's just a matter of waiting until summer??
pro: we can finally live some sort of life again.
we are on the waiting list for several good homes but my understanding is that she will not get into them for many years due to waitlists.
so in order to get into a home at all, we will need to go into crisis.
this is the root of the problem.
-- she is not ready for that.
how can we get her into a home that gives her dementia care?
i remember the alzheimer's society mentioned a temporary respite place called nora's house.
this sounded amazing to us but it, too, has been closed since last year with no sign of re-opening.
open to ideas or any information anyone has.
she needs 24/7 supervision.
but our options seem so limited.
pro: maybe it's just a matter of waiting until summer??
2) go in to crisis and get her into a home.
pro: we can finally live some sort of life again.
-- she is not ready for that.
in fact, i'm certain it would make things worse.
i remember the alzheimer's society mentioned a temporary respite place called nora's house.
this sounded amazing to us but it, too, has been closed since last year with no sign of re-opening.
open to ideas or any information anyone has.

context: wondering if anyone out there might have any suggestions for us? my mother is a very physically healthy and active 71 year old but is also very much in the grips of moderate dementia. she needs 24/7 supervision. she used to be easy to take care of but because of the closures of her day program, she has been acting out and making life very difficult for us for the past year.  as the future of this pandemic is still up-in-the-air with no definite timeline, and no indication of when her day program or any other supports will open again  we are now considering if it is time to put her in a home. but our options seem so limited. i feel like we only have 2 basic options and neither suit us well:  1) continue to keep her home. use the 20 hours-a-month caregiver respite + scrounge around for any private home care we can find and just try and hang on until the pandemic is over. pro: maybe it's just a matter of waiting until summer?? con: we are so very tired of this and really are facing caregiver burnout. 2) go in to crisis and get her into a home. pro: we can finally live some sort of life again. con: correct me if i'm wrong, but going into crisis would mean that she goes into any nursing home they can find. we are on the waiting list for several good homes but my understanding is that she will not get into them for many years due to waitlists. so in order to get into a home at all, we will need to go into crisis. another problem is that she needs stimulation. this is the root of the problem. she needs specific dementia care. which requires a lot of attention and some sort of social activity. i don't think these are things you get at a nursing home. in fact, my experience is that they basically just lock them in a room and give them the basic necessities of food, shower, etc. -- she is not ready for that. in fact, i'm certain it would make things worse. how can we get her into a home that gives her dementia care? i remember the alzheimer's society mentioned a temporary respite place called nora's house. this sounded amazing to us but it, too, has been closed since last year with no sign of re-opening. open to ideas or any information anyone has. thank you.

pro: we can finally live some sort of life again.
-- she is not ready for that.

i remember the alzheimer's society mentioned a temporary respite place called nora's house.
this sounded amazing to us but it, too, has been closed since last year with no sign of re-opening.
open to ideas or any information anyone has.

context: wondering if anyone out there might have any suggestions for us? my mother is a very physically healthy and active 71 year old but is also very much in the grips of moderate dementia. she needs 24/7 supervision. she used to be easy to take care of but because of the closures of her day program, she has been acting out and making life very difficult for us for the past year.  as the future of this pandemic is still up-in-the-air with no definite timeline, and no indication of when her day program or any other supports will open again  we are now considering if it is time to put her in a home. but our options seem so limited. i feel like we only have 2 basic options and neither suit us well:  1) continue to keep her home. use the 20 hours-a-month caregiver respite + scrounge around for any private home care we can find and just try and hang on until the pandemic is over. pro: maybe it's just a matter of waiting until summer?? con: we are so very tired of this and really are facing caregiver burnout. 2) go in to crisis and get her into a home. pro: we can finally live some sort of life again. con: correct me if i'm wrong, but going into crisis would mean that she goes into any nursing home they can find. we are on the waiting list for several good homes but my understanding is that she will not get into them for many years due to waitlists. so in order to get into a home at all, we will need to go into crisis. another problem is that she needs stimulation. this is the root of the problem. she needs specific dementia care. which requires a lot of attention and some sort of social activity. i don't think these are things you get at a nursing home. in fact, my experience is that they basically just lock them in a room and give them the basic necessities of food, shower, etc. -- she is not ready for that. in fact, i'm certain it would make things worse. how can we get her into a home that gives her dementia care? i remember the alzheimer's society mentioned a temporary respite place called nora's house. this sounded amazing to us but it, too, has been closed since last year with no sign of re-opening. open to ideas or any information anyone has. thank you.

qas.question: have you found things to become more efficient?

answers.text: i set up everything, medication, meals, clothing, anything they need to keep them on a schedule but it's just in slow motion.
my elderly relative and i are now fully vaccinated and my hope was to get them back in the world and seeing their friends for dinner or lunch.
every bowl of cereal takes an hour to eat, every time they sit on the toilet its an ordeal taking of pants shoes underwear.
the nighttime routine brushing teeth, flossing teeth eye drops, changing sock is an hour and a half.
a shower can only happen at most twice per week because it takes two hours and completely wipes them out.
i set up everything, medication, meals, clothing, anything they need to keep them on a schedule but it's just in slow motion.
things that make the day go smoothly?

we've started the process with hospice to find him a care home.

i'm supposed to get my second covid shot next week, which i can't miss.
nor can i take care of him afterwards, because i don't know how it will affect me (extreme drowsiness is extremely common after the 2nd dose).

i'm just so worried and have no idea what else to do.

context: i was dad's full-time caregiver for 8 months, until it caused such severe burnout that i had a mental breakdown. then, mom stepped back in to become his caregiver (two months ago). well, mom got hurt taking care of him, so i'm caregiver again. he is on hospice this time around, but they only come out like 2x each week (mostly just for a quick change and a bath). he requires constant around-the-clock care, and i already feel the burnout setting back in. what's worse, is this coming month is extremely important for me, as i'm supposed to be moving out... but i can't even prepare for that while taking care of him. we've started the process with hospice to find him a care home. however, they won't be here until later this week. i'm supposed to get my second covid shot next week, which i can't miss. nor can i take care of him afterwards, because i don't know how it will affect me (extreme drowsiness is extremely common after the 2nd dose). but if i can't take care of him, who will? i'm just so worried and have no idea what else to do. what do y'all think?

answers.text: no one ever knew how he was doing financially as he never talked about money, not even his income.
i'm the first person to ever have access to his checking account via online banking.
he doesn't like people messing with his stuff.
he won't pay bills online as he doesn't trust it, etc.
my 80 year old father has dementia and while it's not super terrible, it's getting pretty bad.
he's always been very proud and private.
no one ever knew how he was doing financially as he never talked about money, not even his income.
he doesn't like people messing with his stuff.
he won't pay bills online as he doesn't trust it, etc.
not when he forgets my name, or how to make his signature, or how to turn off the stove.
not when he can't remember how to turn on the tv, or where the shampoo is in the shower, or how to put on underwear.
i'm just worried he'll shoot it down the second the request leaves my mouth due to his pride, independence, privacy, and denial.

context: my 80 year old father has dementia and while it's not super terrible, it's getting pretty bad. i'm having to pay all his bills for him and have him just sign the checks, and that's been okay for a while but now he's forgetting how to sign his name. i'm not on any of his accounts so it's getting a bit scary as once he slips beyond a certain point we'll both be kinda screwed. he's always been very proud and private. no one ever knew how he was doing financially as he never talked about money, not even his income. i'm the first person to ever have access to his checking account via online banking. he doesn't like people messing with his stuff. he won't pay bills online as he doesn't trust it, etc. he also doesn't seem to think there's anything wrong with him. not when he forgets my name, or how to make his signature, or how to turn off the stove. not when he can't remember how to turn on the tv, or where the shampoo is in the shower, or how to put on underwear. i really need to get a poa from him before it's too late because i heard getting guardianship is a much longer/harder process. i'm just worried he'll shoot it down the second the request leaves my mouth due to his pride, independence, privacy, and denial. anyone have any success in getting a poa from a loved one in this situation? any tips for me on how to approach it with him?

qas.question: my question is: is it time to invoke the poa and take over all her finances?

answers.text: in 2009 she had cancer and wanted to make sure everything was taken care of and she signed a power of attorney making me her poa.
over the last 2-4 years she has been making large purchases without speaking with me.

i do a budget at the beginning of the month and i ask that she loosely stick to it and if either of us wanted to make a large purchase we would discuss it as one of us spending a lot of money effects the other person's finances.
i have been trying to keep her on a budget for years but she buys shit she doesn't need, she buys from scam sites, she makes mistakes in ordering, i could go on and on.
she has her own checking account.
we are both on disability, she get's more than i do yet every month on cue she is broke by week 2-3 and i get to pay for everything for her.
her food, her medicine, her medical bills, her transportation, i could keep going on.
i don't want to have to take away what little financial freedom she has but every month it effects my bank account as i have to pay for/cover everything after she runs out of money.
i spend hours a week taking care of her and have never even considered being financially compensated, it was just a labor of love and i know no one can take care of her better than i can.
she's only 52 so she will probably fight me tooth and nail if i tried to take over her finances but she doesn't give a shit about money, if she thinks she might need it she will buy it.
i don't want to get hardcore here, i already told her i would have some tough decisions to make when our lease is up since i'm just not happy with my/our current situation.
in 2009 she had cancer and wanted to make sure everything was taken care of and she signed a power of attorney making me her poa.
luckily i can't remember a time when i needed to invoke it except once at housing court when she was in the hospital and couldn't make it to court.
over the last 2-4 years she has been making large purchases without speaking with me.
i have been trying to keep her on a budget for years but she buys shit she doesn't need, she buys from scam sites, she makes mistakes in ordering, i could go on and on.
she has her own checking account.
we are both on disability, she get's more than i do yet every month on cue she is broke by week 2-3 and i get to pay for everything for her.
her food, her medicine, her medical bills, her transportation, i could keep going on.
she ignores any financial advice i give and promises to stick to our budget then never does.
i believe a promise is a promise.
she makes these promises and doesn't stick to them or follow through with them.
i don't want to have to take away what little financial freedom she has but every month it effects my bank account as i have to pay for/cover everything after she runs out of money.
i spend hours a week taking care of her and have never even considered being financially compensated, it was just a labor of love and i know no one can take care of her better than i can.
she's only 52 so she will probably fight me tooth and nail if i tried to take over her finances but she doesn't give a shit about money, if she thinks she might need it she will buy it.

context: here is my issue: i have been taking care of my mother since about 2010, and a bit from 08-09. i also took care of her when i was a little kid. i've been living with her since 2015 in a small apartment that is very, very, small. in 2009 she had cancer and wanted to make sure everything was taken care of and she signed a power of attorney making me her poa. luckily i can't remember a time when i needed to invoke it except once at housing court when she was in the hospital and couldn't make it to court. over the last 2-4 years she has been making large purchases without speaking with me. i do a budget at the beginning of the month and i ask that she loosely stick to it and if either of us wanted to make a large purchase we would discuss it as one of us spending a lot of money effects the other person's finances. i have been trying to keep her on a budget for years but she buys shit she doesn't need, she buys from scam sites, she makes mistakes in ordering, i could go on and on.  she has her own checking account. we are both on disability, she get's more than i do yet every month on cue she is broke by week 2-3 and i get to pay for everything for her. her food, her medicine, her medical bills, her transportation, i could keep going on. she ignores any financial advice i give and promises to stick to our budget then never does. i believe a promise is a promise. she makes these promises and doesn't stick to them or follow through with them. she got upset tonight because i told her that her word meant nothing to me because she can't agree to things she promised she would do as agreed upon by both of us.  my question is: is it time to invoke the poa and take over all her finances? i feel like it's kind of a scorched earth policy if i do that but it may be time. i had her evaluated by a neuropsychologist and she said my mother's iq is 71, just one point from making her mentally challenged. i don't want to have to take away what little financial freedom she has but every month it effects my bank account as i have to pay for/cover everything after she runs out of money.  i spend hours a week taking care of her and have never even considered being financially compensated, it was just a labor of love and i know no one can take care of her better than i can. i just want us both to be happy and right now one of us is always unhappy and most of the time it is me. she's only 52 so she will probably fight me tooth and nail if i tried to take over her finances but she doesn't give a shit about money, if she thinks she might need it she will buy it. i don't want to get hardcore here, i already told her i would have some tough decisions to make when our lease is up since i'm just not happy with my/our current situation.

qas.question: does anyone have tips for dealing with uncooperative behavior?

answers.text: "the snake in the stomach" doesnt want any of it.
i can handle a little pushback but i'm starting to believe she just wants to see how much she can get away with making me accommodate her.
obviously, the physical abuse isn't really a problem anymore.
and for the first couple weeks, we got along fine.
i have a list prepared of all her favorite foods, and i proceed to read them to her.
"the snake in the stomach" doesnt want any of it.
once i reach the end of my rope, i proceed to start bringing in food i bought for myself and my fiance, all of which she also rejects.
i'm worried that if she continues to refuse to eat her food i've prepared, it will negatively impact her health.

context: i'm 25(m) and my fiance (20f) are caregiving for my 91 year old grandmother. my grandmother was physically, mentally and verbally abusive to her children when she was younger. she's completely lucid. obviously, the physical abuse isn't really a problem anymore. and for the first couple weeks, we got along fine. but she has recently started to get more demanding. every time i come down to offer her food, she complains about how something is wrong with the meal, how something she enjoyed a week ago is now terrible and she hates it, etc. only to change her mind and ask for it again days later. and every time, i've bent over backwards to correct it running myself ragged and even driving across town late and night to the grocery store to pick her out things she would rather eat. there has to be a better solution. my fiance has cared for disabled family her whole life and is a phenomenal cook, but shes met her match with my grandmother. to give an example, one time, she summons me into her room and says shes hungry. i have a list prepared of all her favorite foods, and i proceed to read them to her. one by one, they are all rejected. word for word, she starts by saying "i dont know what i want to eat." "the snake in the stomach" doesnt want any of it. once i reach the end of my rope, i proceed to start bringing in food i bought for myself and my fiance, all of which she also rejects. shes literally refused every meal in the house. eventually, she says, "i just want a milkshake. that's all i'm willing to eat." i made her one, but i'm really bothered by the idea that "the stomach" will continue to make me bend over backwards and play long guessing games, even when i don't have money to keep buying new groceries every day. the latest thing she's started to do is throw the food and even toss the plates off the table, insulting the effort we put into preparing for us and saying bad things about us in spanish. our family friend brought over a dish they prepared as a gift for her, and she wasted all of it by throwing the meat on the floor because i didn't cut the meat correctly. i'm worried that if she continues to refuse to eat her food i've prepared, it will negatively impact her health.  does anyone have tips for dealing with uncooperative behavior? i can handle a little pushback but i'm starting to believe she just wants to see how much she can get away with making me accommodate her. thank you.

qas.question: what kind of things do you guys cook for individuals?

answers.text: hi everyone, i hope youre all well!
so a bit of background.
im 21, and a biology student.
im hoping to become a physician associate (physician assistant if youre in america) so educationally im on track, but i really need to gain work experience.
im pretty aware of what the role consists of, but i just need advice.
im also aware that i may have to cook for residents, which is a daunting task as i always avoid cooking meat as im terrified of giving someone food poisoning!
how often do you wash bedding/use the washing machine?
this may sound so silly but i just need advice for this.
please no negative comments, im really just here for advice.
im very much aware of the challenges that are involved when working in care.
im 21, and a biology student.
im hoping to become a physician associate (physician assistant if youre in america) so educationally im on track, but i really need to gain work experience.
i worked in care home before, when i had just turned 18. i absolutely enjoyed working with the elderly residents, but couldnt deal with the toxicity of some of the staff.
i live at home still, and am very lucky to have my dad cook for me and the family, and my mum popping my washing in the washing machine.
this may sound so silly but i just need advice for this.
thank you guys!

qas.question: can i physically and emotionally give my mom support in a way that reflects the immense love that i feel for her?

answers.text: i could go on for hours about my situation and all of the nuances, but will keep this post as short and straight to the point as possible.
that phone call turned my life completely upside down.
...not to mention the stress, mental health crises, financial burden, etc.
we have 24/7 nurses at the house, but eventually they have to use the bathroom, empty my moms catheter, change her feeding tube bag, refill her water, etc.
my dad has serious caregiver fatigue and leaves the house for 5-8 hours every day because he cant deal.
ive known for awhile that it isnt sustainable, but it fucking kills me to see the look on my moms face when one of us isnt there when shes struggling.
i want to give them everything.
but i have nothing to give anymore.
in october 2020, when i was 16 weeks pregnant with my first child, my dad called to inform me that (1) my mom had been diagnosed with als and (2) shed attempted suicide that previous afternoon.
will the relationship with my babys father crumble under the stress?
...not to mention the stress, mental health crises, financial burden, etc.
that i was already dealing with due to the pandemic.
fast forward to now: i had a healthy baby girl in february and she has been an angel.
but now, while still on maternity leave, im staying with my parents to help take care of my mom (and the newborn).

my mom cannot be alone for more than 10 seconds because she has a very aggressive form of als that makes her choke frequently - someone always needs to be there to quickly bring her breathing machine over so that she doesnt die from respiratory failure.
we have 24/7 nurses at the house, but eventually they have to use the bathroom, empty my moms catheter, change her feeding tube bag, refill her water, etc.
so im there to pick up the slack.
meanwhile, im burning the candle at both ends.
like changing adult diapers and newborn diapers literally at the same time.
i try so hard to find and focus on any shred of joy in life anymore, but it isnt there.
i want my daughter and mother to know that theyre both the center of my world.

context: i could go on for hours about my situation and all of the nuances, but will keep this post as short and straight to the point as possible. in october 2020, when i was 16 weeks pregnant with my first child, my dad called to inform me that (1) my mom had been diagnosed with als and (2) shed attempted suicide that previous afternoon. that phone call turned my life completely upside down. it was a time where most people feel elated/excited about bringing the familys first grandchild into the world - but instead my life became consumed with grief and guilt.  will i be able to give me daughter all of the attention and support that she needs to thrive and to love me? can i physically and emotionally give my mom support in a way that reflects the immense love that i feel for her? will the relationship with my babys father crumble under the stress? ...not to mention the stress, mental health crises, financial burden, etc. that i was already dealing with due to the pandemic.  fast forward to now: i had a healthy baby girl in february and she has been an angel. i count my lucky stars every day for her and dont know what i ever did to deserve such a perfect baby.  but now, while still on maternity leave, im staying with my parents to help take care of my mom (and the newborn). my mom cannot be alone for more than 10 seconds because she has a very aggressive form of als that makes her choke frequently - someone always needs to be there to quickly bring her breathing machine over so that she doesnt die from respiratory failure. we have 24/7 nurses at the house, but eventually they have to use the bathroom, empty my moms catheter, change her feeding tube bag, refill her water, etc. so im there to pick up the slack.  my dad has serious caregiver fatigue and leaves the house for 5-8 hours every day because he cant deal. my mom thinks that shes a burden because my dad doesnt want to stick around the house all day every day. meanwhile, im burning the candle at both ends. like changing adult diapers and newborn diapers literally at the same time. ive known for awhile that it isnt sustainable, but it fucking kills me to see the look on my moms face when one of us isnt there when shes struggling.  i try so hard to find and focus on any shred of joy in life anymore, but it isnt there. i want my daughter and mother to know that theyre both the center of my world. i want to give them everything. but i have nothing to give anymore.

qas.question: did you steal any of my nice things?

answers.text: my current patient is physically and verbally abusive, and although im able to keep both of us safe (she is a fall risk patient, and not physically strong enough to do a lot of damage with her violence), and i have therapy and am strict about keeping my personal days free to recharge etc., but i have twelve hour shifts and this woman seemingly has a bottomless well of energy and it just wears on me.
its constantly (and i mean constantly.
dont break any of my things!
youre going to break everything.
nobody wants you here.
thats the verbal stuff and my main responses are to distract, agree when possible, and be silent when those wont work.

she is on as much xanax and mood stabilizers and antipsychotics and stuff as the doctors will give her because shes a fall risk patient and the family doesnt want to medicate further due to what the doctor recommends or put her in a nursing home due to covid, which is understandable.
im on the verge of quitting, honestly.
any suggestions????
for coughs, sneeze, yawn, stretch, etc.
youre going to break everything.
nobody loves you.
anyway.
thats the verbal stuff and my main responses are to distract, agree when possible, and be silent when those wont work.
that must have been quite a houseful!
what was it like?

and for the physical, i mainly follow her around while shes on a rampage to make sure she doesnt fall while she looks for pictures to throw off the walls and such, but i do need to keep her from her husband because she will be violent towards him if they are in the same room while shes upset, and i also feel like i ought to sometimes say something when shes violent towards me if just for the sake of my own sanity.
any suggestions????
screaming to the void here   (also for the record the family is extremely supportive and pays well, and do what they can, but these situations are always difficult, of course.)

context: content warnings: death threats, verbal/physical abuse i understand the concept of maintaining personal boundaries to prevent burnout and such, but i get stuck sometimes on what words to use. my current patient is physically and verbally abusive, and although im able to keep both of us safe (she is a fall risk patient, and not physically strong enough to do a lot of damage with her violence), and i have therapy and am strict about keeping my personal days free to recharge etc., but i have twelve hour shifts and this woman seemingly has a bottomless well of energy and it just wears on me. its constantly (and i mean constantly. 30 seconds of silence seems to be the max.) things like:  no coughing/sneezing/yawning! or stop that!! for coughs, sneeze, yawn, stretch, etc. dont break any of my things! mind you dont get your dirty hands on anything! take it easy! youre going to break everything. did you steal any of my nice things? while im putting away dishes, folding laundry, etc. you poisoned me! when i give her food or water or medicine. youre too fat, dont break my furniture! (lol) hussy/damned fool/idiot girl/etc etc etc (i do appreciate feeling like im in a noir film but still. it starts to sting a bit.) you cant do anything right, i have to order you around. youre good for nothing. nobody loves you. nobody wants you here. i wish someone would kill you. i will burn your house down with you in it. etc etc etc etc  you get the gist. anyway. thats the verbal stuff and my main responses are to distract, agree when possible, and be silent when those wont work. like, seriously, how do you even respond to a disoriented dementia patient saying i wish someone would kill you. ???? so i say things like, ill be careful, im just putting away laundry! and ........you have six kids, right? that must have been quite a houseful! what was it like?  and for the physical, i mainly follow her around while shes on a rampage to make sure she doesnt fall while she looks for pictures to throw off the walls and such, but i do need to keep her from her husband because she will be violent towards him if they are in the same room while shes upset, and i also feel like i ought to sometimes say something when shes violent towards me if just for the sake of my own sanity. i say things like i really need you to stay sitting on the couch with me right now because im worried youre going to fall! and [name] you may not hit me/throw things at me/spit at me/etc. but both do very little.  she is on as much xanax and mood stabilizers and antipsychotics and stuff as the doctors will give her because shes a fall risk patient and the family doesnt want to medicate further due to what the doctor recommends or put her in a nursing home due to covid, which is understandable. im on the verge of quitting, honestly.  i just am out of things to say that remind me (and ideally her too) that im a person, not a well trained dog, and her emotions and such do not come above mine as long as she is physically safe and has the minimum of emotional support that i can manage without burning out. i feel like i need to put affirmations up or something. idk. any suggestions???? screaming to the void here   (also for the record the family is extremely supportive and pays well, and do what they can, but these situations are always difficult, of course.)

qas.question: whats yalls living situation?what kind of precautions are yall taking at this point in the pandemic?

answers.text: in march 2020 when everything shut down i stopped doing everything.
i kept working my part time job up until september 2020 when i realized covid wasnt going away, and i felt guilty putting my household at risk.
my main question is what is the middle ground at this point?
its bothering way more than i can explain that i havent had any social interaction in over a year and i wanna get back out and just do a couple things at some point.
i want to get a relative safe job and go back to the gym.
those are the two things that used to keep my sane.
when will yall / when did yall step out and take the risk?
i just want to hear yalls situations and realize im not alone.
maybe some things yall have found to relieve stress?
my dad has had to postpone his due to doctors orders but should get his first one started next month hopefully.
since then i have had literally no social interaction with anyone my age and the only ones i do have with people outside of my family are medical related for caregiving.
frankly im tired of going to the park alone to do push ups alone.
i just want to hear yalls situations and realize im not alone.

context: whats yalls living situation?what kind of precautions are yall taking at this point in the pandemic?  i moved to a new state to be a caregiver 5 months before the pandemic, therefore i dont know many people im 22 living with my dad (52, pretty bad ms who i care for), and his parents (73 and 75, they see relatively healthy). now my grandparents are both fully vaccinated and i will be in a couple weeks. my dad has had to postpone his due to doctors orders but should get his first one started next month hopefully.  in march 2020 when everything shut down i stopped doing everything. i kept working my part time job up until september 2020 when i realized covid wasnt going away, and i felt guilty putting my household at risk. since then i have had literally no social interaction with anyone my age and the only ones i do have with people outside of my family are medical related for caregiving.  without going into it too much, september up to now has been sooooo rough, i just typed out a whole page to try to explain what im going through and cant even get through the half of it lol. thats what kind of pandemic its been, im sure yall can relate. my main question is what is the middle ground at this point? its bothering way more than i can explain that i havent had any social interaction in over a year and i wanna get back out and just do a couple things at some point. frankly im tired of going to the park alone to do push ups alone.  i want to get a relative safe job and go back to the gym. those are the two things that used to keep my sane.  when will yall / when did yall step out and take the risk?  do yall think i should start to wear a mask in my home? my grandparents still run errands and do some things on occasion, im the only one who stays in the house all the time.  i just want to hear yalls situations and realize im not alone. maybe some things yall have found to relieve stress?

context: whats yalls living situation?what kind of precautions are yall taking at this point in the pandemic?  i moved to a new state to be a caregiver 5 months before the pandemic, therefore i dont know many people im 22 living with my dad (52, pretty bad ms who i care for), and his parents (73 and 75, they see relatively healthy). now my grandparents are both fully vaccinated and i will be in a couple weeks. my dad has had to postpone his due to doctors orders but should get his first one started next month hopefully.  in march 2020 when everything shut down i stopped doing everything. i kept working my part time job up until september 2020 when i realized covid wasnt going away, and i felt guilty putting my household at risk. since then i have had literally no social interaction with anyone my age and the only ones i do have with people outside of my family are medical related for caregiving.  without going into it too much, september up to now has been sooooo rough, i just typed out a whole page to try to explain what im going through and cant even get through the half of it lol. thats what kind of pandemic its been, im sure yall can relate. my main question is what is the middle ground at this point? its bothering way more than i can explain that i havent had any social interaction in over a year and i wanna get back out and just do a couple things at some point. frankly im tired of going to the park alone to do push ups alone.  i want to get a relative safe job and go back to the gym. those are the two things that used to keep my sane.  when will yall / when did yall step out and take the risk?  do yall think i should start to wear a mask in my home? my grandparents still run errands and do some things on occasion, im the only one who stays in the house all the time.  i just want to hear yalls situations and realize im not alone. maybe some things yall have found to relieve stress?

qas.question: when will yall / when did yall step out and take the risk?

context: i have been trying to find essays, books, podcasts, etc. about the experience of being a caregiver, in their late 20s, taking care of a significant other. my significant other and i have been together for several years and he has been being treated for cancer for over a year. i periodically will look for things to read that would help me think through the feelings/challenges i have had during this process. there are some resource pages but i have not managed to find anything substantial from working-age caregivers talking about their experience taking care of a significant other. thank you in advance! specific materials of interest though would be curious to read works from a range of mediums:  essays columns books blogs  bonus points if the writer is...  gay no children working  ... or discusses...  self-care (while upholding the quality of care for the sick family member) trying to succeed at work despite sometimes-crippling anxiety (and depression?) challenges from covid-19

qas.question: should i have waited to say something?

answers.text: cue the start of my midlife crisis.

our house, the animals (2cats and a dog), cooking, cleaning, gardening, helping him shower or go to the bathroom, picking up prescriptions, helping with his therapy, doing so much laundry, sobbing by myself outside then handwashing 3 days worth of dishes because our dishwasher broke, it's like i woke up in someone else's life.
i'm pretty sure i'm going to get fired at this new job because of poor work performance.
we went through so many shift changes, and so much was lost or forgotten because of this.
we were told we were waiting for an mri, and 6 hours of badgering later, discovered that the previous shift doctor who said he had ordered it hadn't put it in the system.
i also need support and care.
i walk 3 blocks across sky bridges looking for a tampon vending machine that information pointed me towards, no luck.
but whatever, i call an uber to come grab me awhen tom starts begging me to get him something from starbucks.
so i get him a cool hanging plant, nothing fancy, but he loves his houseplants so it fit well.
he got me nothing.
its not about getting a gift, it's about being considered.
am i losing my mind, because i feel like i am.
i just feel like caregiving has shown a glaring spotlight on our relationship and i don't like what i'm seeing.
hi all, i feel like my brain is about to explode so i just need to get his out.
sorry about typos, i'm on mobile.
he could barely walk, and even the barest movement, bend or twist was excruciating.
that same day, i started a new job, and my dad told the family that he has lung cancer.
we went through so many shift changes, and so much was lost or forgotten because of this.
eventually, around hour16, they moved him to a back hallway by the trauma er entrance.
i wasn't able to go with him, and was able to go home and finally rest for a bit.
he is still in a lot of pain, using a walker to get around, can't bend over or do much of anything independently.
still a lot of work and not fun for either of us, but a much needed relief from the hospital balancing act.
i am proud of myself for how hard i have worked to make tom happy and healthy, especially given that my depression has a history of making even basic self care impossible.
it's like he sees me as this endless waterfall of kindness, energy and empathy that never needs to be replinished.
i also need support and care.
sorry i can't seem to stop writing, i don't feel like i can talk about this with anyone, and it's felt good to just get it out.

i know this sounds so nitpicky, because he has been sick, but for the past week since he came home from the hospital he's done nothing but sit on the sofa on his phone, the least he could have done is order a card or plan on ordering dinner.
i've gotten him a small thing each time.

last night i asked if he could order our dinner for the night and he pouted and whinged about having to download the apps and buy it, when i have been the one to order food our entire relationship despite the fact that i make less than $20,000 a year.
he just turned away from me and turned on the tv.
we haven't spoken since, i slept downstairs, other than what's necessary, because i'm still his primary fucking caregiver.
why the fuck am i breaking myself to pieces for you, who cant even be bothered to talk to me, care for me, or say "i love and appreciate you" when i'm literally begging for it?
yet when i had surgery last year you wouldn't even drive me to the hopsital prior and didn't come visit me that night.
can't even do the bare minimum when the roles are reversed.
am i being too hard on him while he's sick?
my brain feels like it's been put in a blender.
i'm just so so so exhausted.
i just feel like caregiving has shown a glaring spotlight on our relationship and i don't like what i'm seeing.
we are incredibly lucky to have them.

context: hi all, i feel like my brain is about to explode so i just need to get his out. sorry about typos, i'm on mobile. i'm new to this community, so i'll give y'all some brief background. my (31f) partner (tom,34m) has a fracture in his lower spine that occasionally gives him issue, but on march 25th of this year, it completely debilitated him. he could barely walk, and even the barest movement, bend or twist was excruciating. that same day, i started a new job, and my dad told the family that he has lung cancer. cue the start of my midlife crisis.  as the weeks passed, toms back was getting increasingly worse and i suddenly found myself his full time caregiver when i wasn't at work. our house, the animals (2cats and a dog), cooking, cleaning, gardening, helping him shower or go to the bathroom, picking up prescriptions, helping with his therapy, doing so much laundry, sobbing by myself outside then handwashing 3 days worth of dishes because our dishwasher broke, it's like i woke up in someone else's life. and i didn't like the pieces of me that i was left with. i didn't even have a chance to deal with my father's cancer, and tom rarely asked. i've struggled with depression and anxiety my entire life, but any form of mental health care has disappeared. i'm pretty sure i'm going to get fired at this new job because of poor work performance. i tried to explain my situation, and it only made things worse.  10 days ago, we took tom to the er. thank god we are both vaccinated, i can't imagine the anxiety otherwise. he had a high fever for about 5 days and we were worried about an infection, although he had already seen several doctors and they did not share our concern, which was incredibly frustrating. we waited for nearly 22 hours to be admitted, with him in excruciating pain the entire time. we went through so many shift changes, and so much was lost or forgotten because of this. we were told we were waiting for an mri, and 6 hours of badgering later, discovered that the previous shift doctor who said he had ordered it hadn't put it in the system. eventually, around hour16, they moved him to a back hallway by the trauma er entrance. i wasn't able to go with him, and was able to go home and finally rest for a bit. he was in this hallway for 6 hours, i'm pretty sure they forgot him. anyway, once he's admitted, over the course of the next few days, we find out he has a strep infection in his spine (i didn't know this was a thing?!?) that took up residence in the spine defect. so even though it sucked sitting through all the er stuff, i am glad i pushed and advocated for him because this could have easily been so so much worse. and i know y'all know how tough hospital stays can be. i felt like i was pulled 1000 directions, making sure he was fed, had clean clothes, taking care of whatever house stuff i could to try and get it ready for him to remove home.  he is home now, with a picc line for the next 6 weeks. he is still in a lot of pain, using a walker to get around, can't bend over or do much of anything independently. still a lot of work and not fun for either of us, but a much needed relief from the hospital balancing act.  anyway, i am struggling with with feeling like i am constantly disappointmenting tom as a caregiver, even though i know how hard i am working and that i am quite literally doing my best. i am proud of myself for how hard i have worked to make tom happy and healthy, especially given that my depression has a history of making even basic self care impossible. but somehow in the past month it's like i've gained superhuman strength to help tom fight this, i'm able to care for tom and take care of myself better than i usually do. yes, there is cat hair on the floor, our garden is dying, the dog needs a long walk, i need to plant this tree, clean out the fridge, take the trash to the street, shave your back, water the plants, schedule a maid, mow the grass, and a million other things, but we are clean and fed, and i am working my ass off to complete the growing list of shit i have to do. so i feel proud even if it's not perfect. but tom has consistently made me feel as though im falling short. complaints about the food, the cleanliness of the house, what i should be doing... i know he is frustrated and in a lot of pain, but i just want to scream at him to open his eyes and have some fucking empathy for me as well throughout all this. it's like he sees me as this endless waterfall of kindness, energy and empathy that never needs to be replinished. this is also hard for me. i also need support and care.  for example. when he was still in the hospital, i had gone home during the day to rest, clean, and restock toms supplies. my brother dropped me off for the night so i wouldnt have to pay for parking or walk through the city alone late at night (#6 highest murder rate in the us ftw). i have to pee when i get there and find the nearest public only to find that i've started my period early, thanks stress, and bled through my pants badly. don't know how i didn't notice, i guess i just thought it was normal vagina things since it was a full 2 weeks early. so i wrap myself up, start my hunt for tampons, and am shit out of luck. i walk 3 blocks across sky bridges looking for a tampon vending machine that information pointed me towards, no luck. can't get an uber, no pharmacy in walking distance or open at this hour. eventually i find a nurse who gives me one tampon and a pad, so i am able to go up to his room and finally change clothes. the pajamas i had grabbed we're some weird ratty old ones, all the rest were in the wash. and of course, the next morning, i have completely bled through the pad, the sheet, probably the floors below us. it was a mess. but whatever, i call an uber to come grab me awhen tom starts begging me to get him something from starbucks. i do not have a change of clothes, because they are also covered in blood, and the only shoes i have are from my outfit last night, and are these chunky clogs with a slight heel. so,i am wearing blood soaked, lime green and blue striped leggings that are covered in holes and these absurd heeled clogs. i smell, i'm embarrassed, i look completely deranged, and i just want to go home and find a super plus 6x tampon and sit in the bathtub. but he wants starbucks, which is 2 skybridges away inside the hospital. i tell him no, explain why, show him my ruined pants, and yet he's persistent and keeps whining that he doesn't know why  i can't just do it, he hates the hospital coffee. i just felt so unheard, unseen, unappreciated, unloved, uncared for. i cried my entire way out of the hospital and in the uber, i don't know why this particular instance just stung me so so bad. i felt so broken and alone.  i couldn't stop crying for hours. not because i still felt those emotions but my eyes just turned in to faucets and wouldn't turn off.  so that's a brief summary. sorry i can't seem to stop writing, i don't feel like i can talk about this with anyone, and it's felt good to just get it out.  on to the main event, or why i feel bad that i don't feel bad. yesterday was our anniversary. we've only been together 2 years, we're not married, so it's not like this is some big hoorah or anything. but it's been a tough year, it would be nice to reconnect with each other. so i get him a cool hanging plant, nothing fancy, but he loves his houseplants so it fit well. he got me nothing. didnt do anything besides say happy anniversary before i left for work. i know this sounds so nitpicky, because he has been sick, but for the past week since he came home from the hospital he's done nothing but sit on the sofa on his phone, the least he could have done is order a card or plan on ordering dinner. and it's not like this is some one time thing, he didn't get me anything last year, and has never gotten me anything for valentine's day. i've gotten him a small thing each time. he makes more than 3x as much as me, thanks to me being a full time grad student for the past 4 years, so money's not the issue. last night i asked if he could order our dinner for the night and he pouted and whinged about having to download the apps and buy it, when i have been the one to order food our entire relationship despite the fact that i make less than $20,000 a year.  something broke inside me when i was practically begging this man who is supposed to love me to just download a god damn app to order us food, so that in my mind i could pretend he cared enough to get me something for our anniversary. we ordered bbq, not some 5 course meal. fucking hell.  so when we sat down to eat, he asked what was wrong and i told him that i've been feeling unappreciated, and that i wouldn't be upset if this was the exception not the rule.  and i told him the following: of course i know he can't go out and shop right now, but i'd be just as happy with a small handwritten note or a cool rock he found outside. its not about getting a gift, it's about being considered. and he wasn't sick for our anniversary last year or the past two valentine's days. but he hemmed and hawed, claiming he did get me something in the past, and that he couldn't believe that i was so hurt over "just a gift". he said "we've had this talk before", which we have, i've asked for more empathy and nothing changed other than now he actually says "thank you" when i do something for him, a skill he should have mastered 30 years ago. so i said "exactly, weve talked about this several times". he just turned away from me and turned on the tv. we haven't spoken since, i slept downstairs, other than what's necessary, because i'm still his primary fucking caregiver.  am i losing my mind, because i feel like i am. why the fuck am i breaking myself to pieces for you, who cant even be bothered to talk to me, care for me, or say "i love and appreciate you" when i'm literally begging for it? i'm not your wife, i clean your ass and cook your food and bend over backwards because i care about you. yet when i had surgery last year you wouldn't even drive me to the hopsital prior and didn't come visit me that night. can't even do the bare minimum when the roles are reversed. does he just not care? would that make this easier? am i just asking for  too much and putting my expectations on to him? am i blowing things out of proportion because i am just too tired and emotional? am i being too hard on him while he's sick? should i have waited to say something?  sorry guys, i clearly needed to rant. my brain feels like it's been put in a blender. i'm just so so so exhausted. maybe this would have been a better fit for relationship advice, so i'm sorry if this is the wrong place. i just feel like caregiving has shown a glaring spotlight on our relationship and i don't like what i'm seeing.  to clarify, we have been fortunate to have a lot of help from both of our parents and his friends, i could not have gotten through this past month alone and i don't want to pretend like that's the case. we are incredibly lucky to have them. and i know i'm not perfect and this is only my side of the story, i've made mistakes too but i just feel so lost right now.  to anyone who makes it this far, thanks for reading.

qas.question: why the fuck am i breaking myself to pieces for you, who cant even be bothered to talk to me, care for me, or say "i love and appreciate you" when i'm literally begging for it?

but we are clean and fed, and i am working my ass off to complete the growing list of shit i have to do. so i feel proud even if it's not perfect. but tom has consistently made me feel as though im falling short. complaints about the food, the cleanliness of the house, what i should be doing... i know he is frustrated and in a lot of pain, but i just want to scream at him to open his eyes and have some fucking empathy for me as well throughout all this. it's like he sees me as this endless waterfall of kindness, energy and empathy that never needs to be replinished. this is also hard for me. i also need support and care.  for example. when he was still in the hospital, i had gone home during the day to rest, clean, and restock toms supplies. my brother dropped me off for the night so i wouldnt have to pay for parking or walk through the city alone late at night (#6 highest murder rate in the us ftw). i have to pee when i get there and find the nearest public only to find that i've started my period early, thanks stress, and bled through my pants badly. don't know how i didn't notice, i guess i just thought it was normal vagina things since it was a full 2 weeks early. so i wrap myself up, start my hunt for tampons, and am shit out of luck. i walk 3 blocks across sky bridges looking for a tampon vending machine that information pointed me towards, no luck. can't get an uber, no pharmacy in walking distance or open at this hour. eventually i find a nurse who gives me one tampon and a pad, so i am able to go up to his room and finally change clothes. the pajamas i had grabbed we're some weird ratty old ones, all the rest were in the wash. and of course, the next morning, i have completely bled through the pad, the sheet, probably the floors below us. it was a mess. but whatever, i call an uber to come grab me awhen tom starts begging me to get him something from starbucks. i do not have a change of clothes, because they are also covered in blood, and the only shoes i have are from my outfit last night, and are these chunky clogs with a slight heel. so,i am wearing blood soaked, lime green and blue striped leggings that are covered in holes and these absurd heeled clogs. i smell, i'm embarrassed, i look completely deranged, and i just want to go home and find a super plus 6x tampon and sit in the bathtub. but he wants starbucks, which is 2 skybridges away inside the hospital. i tell him no, explain why, show him my ruined pants, and yet he's persistent and keeps whining that he doesn't know why  i can't just do it, he hates the hospital coffee. i just felt so unheard, unseen, unappreciated, unloved, uncared for. i cried my entire way out of the hospital and in the uber, i don't know why this particular instance just stung me so so bad. i felt so broken and alone.  i couldn't stop crying for hours. not because i still felt those emotions but my eyes just turned in to faucets and wouldn't turn off.  so that's a brief summary. sorry i can't seem to stop writing, i don't feel like i can talk about this with anyone, and it's felt good to just get it out.  on to the main event, or why i feel bad that i don't feel bad. yesterday was our anniversary. we've only been together 2 years, we're not married, so it's not like this is some big hoorah or anything. but it's been a tough year, it would be nice to reconnect with each other. so i get him a cool hanging plant, nothing fancy, but he loves his houseplants so it fit well. he got me nothing. didnt do anything besides say happy anniversary before i left for work. i know this sounds so nitpicky, because he has been sick, but for the past week since he came home from the hospital he's done nothing but sit on the sofa on his phone, the least he could have done is order a card or plan on ordering dinner. and it's not like this is some one time thing, he didn't get me anything last year, and has never gotten me anything for valentine's day. i've gotten him a small thing each time. he makes more than 3x as much as me, thanks to me being a full time grad student for the past 4 years, so money's not the issue. last night i asked if he could order our dinner for the night and he pouted and whinged about having to download the apps and buy it, when i have been the one to order food our entire relationship despite the fact that i make less than $20,000 a year.  something broke inside me when i was practically begging this man who is supposed to love me to just download a god damn app to order us food, so that in my mind i could pretend he cared enough to get me something for our anniversary. we ordered bbq, not some 5 course meal. fucking hell.  so when we sat down to eat, he asked what was wrong and i told him that i've been feeling unappreciated, and that i wouldn't be upset if this was the exception not the rule.  and i told him the following: of course i know he can't go out and shop right now, but i'd be just as happy with a small handwritten note or a cool rock he found outside. its not about getting a gift, it's about being considered. and he wasn't sick for our anniversary last year or the past two valentine's days. but he hemmed and hawed, claiming he did get me something in the past, and that he couldn't believe that i was so hurt over "just a gift". he said "we've had this talk before", which we have, i've asked for more empathy and nothing changed other than now he actually says "thank you" when i do something for him, a skill he should have mastered 30 years ago. so i said "exactly, weve talked about this several times". he just turned away from me and turned on the tv. we haven't spoken since, i slept downstairs, other than what's necessary, because i'm still his primary fucking caregiver.  am i losing my mind, because i feel like i am. why the fuck am i breaking myself to pieces for you, who cant even be bothered to talk to me, care for me, or say "i love and appreciate you" when i'm literally begging for it? i'm not your wife, i clean your ass and cook your food and bend over backwards because i care about you. yet when i had surgery last year you wouldn't even drive me to the hopsital prior and didn't come visit me that night. can't even do the bare minimum when the roles are reversed. does he just not care? would that make this easier? am i just asking for  too much and putting my expectations on to him? am i blowing things out of proportion because i am just too tired and emotional? am i being too hard on him while he's sick? should i have waited to say something?  sorry guys, i clearly needed to rant. my brain feels like it's been put in a blender. i'm just so so so exhausted. maybe this would have been a better fit for relationship advice, so i'm sorry if this is the wrong place. i just feel like caregiving has shown a glaring spotlight on our relationship and i don't like what i'm seeing.  to clarify, we have been fortunate to have a lot of help from both of our parents and his friends, i could not have gotten through this past month alone and i don't want to pretend like that's the case. we are incredibly lucky to have them. and i know i'm not perfect and this is only my side of the story, i've made mistakes too but i just feel so lost right now.  to anyone who makes it this far, thanks for reading.

our house, the animals (2cats and a dog), cooking, cleaning, gardening, helping him shower or go to the bathroom, picking up prescriptions, helping with his therapy, doing so much laundry, sobbing by myself outside then handwashing 3 days worth of dishes because our dishwasher broke, it's like i woke up in someone else's life.
