qas.question: why doesn't familymember visit anymore?

answers.text: pros:  she wasn't really all that dependent, so we had an extra set of hands.
it wasn't emergent that she moved in, so there was no rush when she inevitably fell to get her room and all settled before she returned home from the rehab... everything was as she left it.
so my great-grandmother was always there to read to us, have an afternoon snack with us, play with us.
we don't work together much anymore... it's mostly her needing me.
pros:  she wasn't really all that dependent, so we had an extra set of hands.
it wasn't emergent that she moved in, so there was no rush when she inevitably fell to get her room and all settled before she returned home from the rehab... everything was as she left it.
so my great-grandmother was always there to read to us, have an afternoon snack with us, play with us.
which i don't mind, it's just heartbreaking because, to me, the change feels drastic, so i know she feels that way too.
do you think i'll get better?
she won't ask anyone else those questions and that's fine, but it weighs on me because i get mad at the relatives that don't check in on her.
points to consider, i guess.

context: by early, i mean before the need for constant assistance is there. my grandmother moved in with me two years ago, when her parkinson's symptoms were very minor. she was just afraid to live alone in case she fell, and grocery runs were getting harder for her, so having her move in then was more of a roommate situation.  pros:  she wasn't really all that dependent, so we had an extra set of hands. it wasn't emergent that she moved in, so there was no rush when she inevitably fell to get her room and all settled before she returned home from the rehab... everything was as she left it.  the company helped me cope with a weird time in my life... dealing with the postpartum roller coaster of being a new mom, in a new house, with a new baby, a new job working from home, and a new roommate.  she took care of my great-grandmother, and she also picked me and my brother up from school every day. so my great-grandmother was always there to read to us, have an afternoon snack with us, play with us. so it's nice to see my daughter have that same experience that i had.  ​ cons:  i see the small decline, and it is heartbreaking. i see from month to month or year to year what she's losing the ability to do or comprehend.  we've lost most of the "mutually beneficial" relationship. we don't work together much anymore... it's mostly her needing me. which i don't mind, it's just heartbreaking because, to me, the change feels drastic, so i know she feels that way too.  i get the tough questions. "why didn't soandso call? do you think i'll get better? why doesn't familymember visit anymore? do you think i'll live to see xyz?" she won't ask anyone else those questions and that's fine, but it weighs on me because i get mad at the relatives that don't check in on her.  ​ i don't know why i felt the need to share this. maybe you're on the fence about moving in with your loved one. points to consider, i guess.

qas.question: has anyone else experienced this?

answers.text: my feelings of resentment toward the person i care for are at an all-time high.

context: my feelings of resentment toward the person i care for are at an all-time high. over the past month i've lost my cool about 3 times - it's not anger, it's just overall distress, and i need to find a way to redirect these feelings when i get overwhelmed. i can feel myself starting to blame her for things that aren't really her fault. she isn't emotionally or physically healthy enough to be my punching bag. it isn't fair, and i need to get these feelings under control. has anyone else experienced this? do any of you have strategies for managing resentment? (other than respite which at this time is not an option for us.)

qas.question: it's made my struggle with suicidal ideation more difficult than usual & i'm just curious if there's any advice, encouragement, or similar experiences anyone has to share regarding a spouse with psychosis because no one in my daily life can relate to this horror..?

answers.text: be warned now, due to my reservations about posting here for some time, this story is long.
with my husband's blessing, i think it's time i finally vent about this.
i met him shortly after an accident with an ambulance where he was driving that caused ptsd & hyper nerve sensitivity(hns); he also deals with general anxiety & some depression on top of all this.

he's also been self medicating with cannabis for the past 9 years & only recently got an official prescription from a pain clinic for it in 2020, but it's not meant to be a long term solution because it's expensive af.
there's also been concerns from doctors over the years that the cannabis could result in psychotic episodes.
approx 9 months ago he decided to ween off it since he got an actual cannabis prescription from a pain clinic & in time, his mobility improved.

we don't have nor want kids so it's been frustrating for him trying to get a new doctor when the hospital apparently sees nothing wrong with this guy not having his files straight & declined his request.

dramatic changes in behavioral patterns, paranoia, skewed perception of elapsed time, talking to things that weren't there, almost like he was having discussions with these delusions where they'd answer back, stopping normal social contact with his friends online & spending majority of his time either in the bedroom hiding under the covers, or in the shower talking to someone/something.
i was informed a crisis unit may reach out to check on him for updates & that they'd have my number if he couldn't be reached.

me & his father rushed across the city to meet with the officers once they were on site to describe in more detail everything i saw over the past 2 days & how it resembled the first instance before he told me to get out.

to avoid as much confusion & inaccurate judgments as possible, i'll try to provide as much background info as i can as the past 10 years of my life have been a hell of a roller coaster to say the least for which i've had minimal outside support.
i met him shortly after an accident with an ambulance where he was driving that caused ptsd & hyper nerve sensitivity(hns); he also deals with general anxiety & some depression on top of all this.
but i also need to clarify that to me, he's one of the most kind, generous, understanding people i know who's supported & taken care of me when i'm unwell.

when i was finally able to see him again, he'd completely cleared up from the psychosis, he was back to his kind, loving self & told me that if he ever started showing signs again, i should do what i can to get him help & that i have that permission as his spouse/caregiver.

we don't have nor want kids so it's been frustrating for him trying to get a new doctor when the hospital apparently sees nothing wrong with this guy not having his files straight & declined his request.

seemingly small matters at times started meriting larger bursts of anger than necessary & while it wasn't directed at me & he doesn't damage anything, the loudness still triggers some trauma from what i experienced 4 years ago.
he knows the impact his anger can have on me & often tells me to go to another room in the house when he's like that so it doesn't impact me as much, but it still worries me.
this month: now at the start of april, the signs of psychosis started showing themselves again.
to which his parents came & got me & i've been staying at their place ever since.
over the next 2 days, his dad stayed at the house to do renovation work & keep an eye on j's behavior & make sure he didn't hurt himself or damage the property.
the day after returning home, j started back up on the cannabis.
the incident: by day 2, he showing the signs of irritability again, he wouldn't answer his phone, & the discussions/behavior patterns were picking up.
following those instructions, i did just that, but felt really guilty & worried about him.
the sight made me sob uncontrollably & i'm overwhelmed with guilt as i feel it's my fault i couldn't do more to help or stop the psychosis from taking hold again.
i miss my sane husband so much, i miss all the things we'd do together & the way he'd always go out of his way to make me smile or laugh at least once a day.

i miss our bed, & living in our house, i just want our lives to go back to normal so we can keep working towards the future we'd talk about together, but it feels like that reality will never come if he doesn't get the proper help he needs & i'm scared of that uncertainty.
it's painful watching the person you love slowly descend into madness & not know how to stop it or snap them out of it & i feel incredibly alone & guilty in my experience regarding this.
i feel like any shred of happiness or calmness i have rn while he's in the hospital in a rage without my help makes me an awful person.

context: be warned now, due to my reservations about posting here for some time, this story is long. to avoid as much confusion & inaccurate judgments as possible, i'll try to provide as much background info as i can as the past 10 years of my life have been a hell of a roller coaster to say the least for which i've had minimal outside support. with my husband's blessing, i think it's time i finally vent about this.   some history: i'm a 28f & have been a caregiver for my husband, j(35m) for 9 years, we'll have been together 10 years in a matter of months. i met him shortly after an accident with an ambulance where he was driving that caused ptsd & hyper nerve sensitivity(hns); he also deals with general anxiety & some depression on top of all this. let me also clarify by saying he wasn't the one at fault in the accident and the one who hit him literally fled the scene! he deals with a fair bit of anger because of this & from being misunderstood by many doctors he's seen over the years misdiagnosing his ptsd & trying to treat him for bipolar instead which he doesn't have. but i also need to clarify that to me, he's one of the most kind, generous, understanding people i know who's supported & taken care of me when i'm unwell. he encourages me to pursue my own interests alongside taking care of him & has even expressed understanding if i ever wished to vent to reddit as he knows he's not the easiest person to deal with at times because of the frustration he deals with so i needn't feel guilty for talking about him behind his back. he's also been self medicating with cannabis for the past 9 years & only recently got an official prescription from a pain clinic for it in 2020, but it's not meant to be a long term solution because it's expensive af. there's also been concerns from doctors over the years that the cannabis could result in psychotic episodes.  he's been in & out of hospitals over the years infrequently due to these episodes, the last one(4 years ago) getting so bad that he could no longer recognize me & he lashed out. while i sustained no actual injuries, i called 911 in a panic & he was arrested for assault for which the charges were later dropped due to mental illness but was let off with a warning that if it happened again, he may have to go to jail. when i was finally able to see him again, he'd completely cleared up from the psychosis, he was back to his kind, loving self & told me that if he ever started showing signs again, i should do what i can to get him help & that i have that permission as his spouse/caregiver.   fast forward: so for the past 4 years, j had been stable, while he was back on cannabis to help mitigate the pain from his hns, he was also on some mood stabilizing medication that's normally for bipolar. problem is this medication would make his joints lock up to the point he could barely move. approx 9 months ago he decided to ween off it since he got an actual cannabis prescription from a pain clinic & in time, his mobility improved. he still dealt with pain spikes, but he could now actually use his hands again to some degree. both me & his parents were reluctant about him going off the medication at first, but j's really smart, like abnormally high iq smart & is a very logical person who advocated his reasons for doing so well so we agreed that if it felt right to come off it after so much time on it, then maybe it's time. for the past 7 months he seemed fine with the exception of some anger toward one of his doctors, the one that prescribed him the medication that made his joints lock up, because he's been asking how his 2 kids are for the past couple years every time he sees him. we don't have nor want kids so it's been frustrating for him trying to get a new doctor when the hospital apparently sees nothing wrong with this guy not having his files straight & declined his request.  seemingly small matters at times started meriting larger bursts of anger than necessary & while it wasn't directed at me & he doesn't damage anything, the loudness still triggers some trauma from what i experienced 4 years ago. he knows the impact his anger can have on me & often tells me to go to another room in the house when he's like that so it doesn't impact me as much, but it still worries me.   this month: now at the start of april, the signs of psychosis started showing themselves again. dramatic changes in behavioral patterns, paranoia, skewed perception of elapsed time, talking to things that weren't there, almost like he was having discussions with these delusions where they'd answer back, stopping normal social contact with his friends online & spending majority of his time either in the bedroom hiding under the covers, or in the shower talking to someone/something. this time, it seemed like one of the things he was talking to was an imaginary version of me at times. by day 2 of the strange behavior i informed his parents. by day 3 j was getting so riled up by these delusions he told me to "get the f out of my house!" to which his parents came & got me & i've been staying at their place ever since. over the next 2 days, his dad stayed at the house to do renovation work & keep an eye on j's behavior & make sure he didn't hurt himself or damage the property. after 2 days, j requested his dad take him to the hospital. for the first time in 10 years, he went willingly, but then thought his dad lied to the doctors about what he witnessed. he was there for a little over a week & was in denial about the psychosis. after only 2 days of receiving treatment, he released himself against medical advice & returned home. i was informed a crisis unit may reach out to check on him for updates & that they'd have my number if he couldn't be reached. the doctor also advised i don't move back home right away for my safety. the day after returning home, j started back up on the cannabis. i went to visit him to check on him & verify the integrity of my belongings that were still there as well as make sure he had something to eat. he was back into the affectionate, child-like state of day 1 psychosis where he hyper focused just wanting to be near me with some minor out of place discussions with things that weren't there which he dismissed.   the incident: by day 2, he showing the signs of irritability again, he wouldn't answer his phone, & the discussions/behavior patterns were picking up. he didn't acknowledge me as much & was getting really upset about someone who hadn't been in our lives for years, insisting they killed our cat. to clarify, this guy lost our cat while he was suppose to take care of him, and made no effort to find him, but i don't believe he killed him. i made him something to eat & tried to convince him to come off the cannabis to which he agreed to surprisingly fast, kinda passive aggressively, and allowed me to remove the stuff from the house when it was time for me to leave. i also tried to convince him to take the medication the doctor at the hospital prescribed, but he wouldn't take it. i left feeling really worried about him. a couple hours later, i decided to call the crisis unit & express my concerns about his behavior & told them he wasn't going to return the call like they wanted him to. i described the behavior patterns i saw & how i couldn't convince him to take the medication that was suppose to mitigate the rage/psychosis/anxiety & they suggested i request a wellness check which would send non-emergency officers to check on him & determine if he needs to go back to the hospital. following those instructions, i did just that, but felt really guilty & worried about him. me & his father rushed across the city to meet with the officers once they were on site to describe in more detail everything i saw over the past 2 days & how it resembled the first instance before he told me to get out. shortly after another car rolled up saying it was time to take him & that they had a bed ready for him at the hospital; they determined he needed help & force may have to be used to get him back to the hospital. mortified as i knew what was about to ensue, i ran for my in-law's car & we parked further up the street so he wouldn't see us when he was brought out so i wouldn't be blamed because i was the only person he still trusted even in this state.    tldr: for the first time in a few years now, i had to watch the person i love most be carried out of our home by multiple officers & forced into a car as he screamed at the top of his lungs...again. he was readmitted to the hospital despite his incessant protests that he was fine & could look after himself. the sight made me sob uncontrollably & i'm overwhelmed with guilt as i feel it's my fault i couldn't do more to help or stop the psychosis from taking hold again.  i feel like i betrayed his trust because he doesn't know i'm the one who requested the wellness check even tho his parents tell me it was inevitable because he wouldn't answer his phone when they crisis unit called to check on him, & j's the one who told me to do what i could to get him help if he started showing signs of psychosis again tho i'm not sure he remembers..not to mention he's currently in denial about the psychosis. i miss my sane husband so much, i miss all the things we'd do together & the way he'd always go out of his way to make me smile or laugh at least once a day. i miss all our fun/logical conversations & inside jokes. i miss our bed, & living in our house, i just want our lives to go back to normal so we can keep working towards the future we'd talk about together, but it feels like that reality will never come if he doesn't get the proper help he needs & i'm scared of that uncertainty. it's painful watching the person you love slowly descend into madness & not know how to stop it or snap them out of it & i feel incredibly alone & guilty in my experience regarding this. i feel like any shred of happiness or calmness i have rn while he's in the hospital in a rage without my help makes me an awful person. it's made my struggle with suicidal ideation more difficult than usual & i'm just curious if there's any advice, encouragement, or similar experiences anyone has to share regarding a spouse with psychosis because no one in my daily life can relate to this horror..?   once again, i'm surry for the novel, but i felt it better to be thorough as possible rather than skew details & be misunderstood as it's a very complicated situation.

qas.question: any advice to give or suggest books for me to read?

answers.text: this is incredibly hurtful, as i do almost everything for my grandmother and would never lie to her.
when i talk to my grandmother, she denies everything.
she says she loves me and would never talk poorly of me, and that she appreciates everything i do.
does anyone have some similar stories to share?

context: my grandmother is 90 years old, and i do all the cooking and cleaning around the house. it's just the two of us living together. i recently overheard my grandmother telling my family lies about me over the phone. then to confirm my suspicions, my uncle confronted me about what i heard her saying. she said that i am deceptive, and that i lie to her and hide things from her. this is incredibly hurtful, as i do almost everything for my grandmother and would never lie to her.  the worst part is, i think my family believes her. i have absolutely no reason to lie. i thought i was helping by telling my family about how she forgets things, or how she smears feces on the walls and floor. i thought my family would give me assistance helping my grandmother, but everyone seems to think i'm making things up. when i talk to my grandmother, she denies everything. she says she loves me and would never talk poorly of me, and that she appreciates everything i do. i'm fine with doing everything, but i'm having trouble dealing with the fact that she's talking about me behind my back. does anyone have some similar stories to share? any advice to give or suggest books for me to read?

maybe he doesn't need a feeding tube!

grandpa's not eating again, even if they switched the diet to more flavorful things.

context: so i had hope when my grandpa started eating this past weekend. doctor did too, we thought that oh! maybe he doesn't need a feeding tube! all his vitals are doing great.  well, our luck ran out. grandpa's not eating again, even if they switched the diet to more flavorful things. it's hard to do - given it has to be pureed.  so it looks like we're back to the tube plan. i have to go to the hospital after my chores and talk to him about it. him eating 15% every meal isn't enough. does anyone know how it'll feel? does the pain go away after a week or two? if you have experience, what helped to dull the pain? i feel bad putting it in him but we don't really have a choice....

qas.question: can any of you give me advice to things i can do - maybe a soap/hibiclens soak he can just use in the tub that will help?

answers.text: rarely ever uses soap - he's never even bought his own.
i don't bathe him, but his bo and the residue he leaves on surfaces is.. frankly more than i can take.

i have bought him gentle soaps (he says rougher ones irritate his skin - and i believe it, his skin will likely react to anything that pulls oils and grime off), all sorts of cleaning wands, soft and hard bristle, etc.
i need advice and don't know where to turn to.
this is becoming an issue.
can't kick him out even if i wanted to, but i've been falling into the role (unwillingly, but it's my current lot in life) of his caregiver.
i need advice and don't know where to turn to.
i've sat down with him, discussed with him earnestly several times.
today, for the first time, i offered to help him do a deep clean.
approached clinically.
he declined.

context: a long term friend of mine, who is also my roommate, has bad hygiene.   rarely ever uses soap - he's never even bought his own.   can't kick him out even if i wanted to, but i've been falling into the role (unwillingly, but it's my current lot in life) of his caregiver.  i don't bathe him, but his bo and the residue he leaves on surfaces is.. frankly more than i can take.  i have bought him gentle soaps (he says rougher ones irritate his skin - and i believe it, his skin will likely react to anything that pulls oils and grime off), all sorts of cleaning wands, soft and hard bristle, etc.   i need advice and don't know where to turn to.  i've sat down with him, discussed with him earnestly several times.  today, for the first time, i offered to help him do a deep clean.  just once.  approached clinically.   he declined. this is becoming an issue.  can any of you give me advice to things i can do - maybe a soap/hibiclens soak he can just use in the tub that will help?  or a way i can approach him to convince him to take time to actually cleanse himself in the shower?

qas.question: how do i handle this?

answers.text: im not the caregiver.
and other times.
i live around the corner from my niece also.
shes not even 40 yet.
their twins are 3yrs old.
however, and heres the tricky part, i know my niece, she has always been an extremely independent person.
weve talked.
sometimes because i had to, i really was not available.
however, with her condition taking a bad turn and his emotional state understandably overwhelmed, i cant say no if i can help.
ill be overwhelmed emotionally also.
and most of all i want to honor my nieces wishes.
by him or anyone.
its time.
because when he needs it, if one person is not available he can reach out to the next.
he needs to know who to go to.
help.
but i am one of the babysitters for my niece when she goes for her weekly chemo treatments.
and other times.
my niece and i have always been very close.
we are only 17 years apart.
shes not even 40 yet.
ive let him know out family, that i am there for him whenever he needs me.
however, and heres the tricky part, i know my niece, she has always been an extremely independent person.
i know her wishes.
ive been instructed, when shes gone out of town previously to let him do things himself with the girls.
however, with her condition taking a bad turn and his emotional state understandably overwhelmed, i cant say no if i can help.
what im worried about is later, after, i dont want him to lean on me too much after.
i love this girl like my own daughter.
and, i do have my own health issues, as well as a teenager at home, and aging mother, granddaughters, etc.
i want to help and be there for him.
and most of all i want to honor my nieces wishes.
by him or anyone.
i just need some advice from people that have been there, done that.

context: im not the caregiver. but i am one of the babysitters for my niece when she goes for her weekly chemo treatments. and other times. my niece and i have always been very close. we are only 17 years apart. her mother lives out of state, her father, my older brother died several years ago. shes an only child. i live around the corner from my niece also. her husband of course is lost and overwhelmed emotionally. shes not even 40 yet. their twins are 3yrs old. i talk, of should say...listen to him as often as i can. i just let him get it out. i cant give him advice, ive never been where he is. ive let him know out family, that i am there for him whenever he needs me. however, and heres the tricky part, i know my niece, she has always been an extremely independent person. and she has been raising her daughters to be the same. i know her wishes. weve talked. i know her. ive been instructed, when shes gone out of town previously to let him do things himself with the girls. not to run over there for every little thing. he has to be able to do everything with the girls in tow. i have said no to him on occasion. sometimes because i had to, i really was not available. however, with her condition taking a bad turn and his emotional state understandably overwhelmed, i cant say no if i can help. what im worried about is later, after, i dont want him to lean on me too much after. ill be overwhelmed emotionally also. i love this girl like my own daughter. and, i do have my own health issues, as well as a teenager at home, and aging mother, granddaughters, etc. i dont plan on leaving him high and dry. i want to help and be there for him. but i dont want to be his crutch. and most of all i want to honor my nieces wishes. and....i dont want to be seen as the asshole who isnt there for him and says no to him. by him or anyone. how do i handle this?  i did tell him he should talk to a professional. it would a good idea. and there is grief counseling. i plan on telling him to circle all of his wagons. its time. because when he needs it, if one person is not available he can reach out to the next. he needs to know who to go to.  i just need some advice from people that have been there, done that. or are there doing that. help.

qas.question: did he not recognize me?

answers.text: he's gotten noticeably worse the past few days.
i think it was 3 days ago that he asked me if i'd fed the kids yet (i only have one child and he's an adult that makes his own meals most the time).
part of me is freaking out because my dad forgot who i was.
part of me almost doesn't care because my dad and i aren't exactly close and i grew up with him largely not in my life so the emotional attachment is almost nil.
having a hard time understanding my emotions surrounding this.
i guess i should have seen this coming.
he's gotten noticeably worse the past few days.
there is no other meghan.
and kinda chuckled.
but over the 20 minutes that have followed, it's really hit me.
why did he ask it the way he did?
(my dad tends to have good days and bad days, maybe this is just bad days and he'll get better soon?)
part of me is freaking out because my dad forgot who i was.
part of me almost doesn't care because my dad and i aren't exactly close and i grew up with him largely not in my life so the emotional attachment is almost nil.
hopefully he doesn't forget who my son is anytime soon, those two are like best buds.

context: i guess i should have seen this coming. he's gotten noticeably worse the past few days. i think it was 3 days ago that he asked me if i'd fed the kids yet (i only have one child and he's an adult that makes his own meals most the time). later that day he asked me if i'd seen my daughter lately (i've never had a daughter, or anyone like a daughter to me, or anything like that). today dad and i were sitting in the living room. him on the couch snuggled with the dog watching bowling on tv. me in the chair next to the couch, fervently crocheting a stuffed dinosaur for a sick friend of mine. he started to speak, and you could tell in his voice that he almost didn't want to ask the question (you know that feeling you get when you're asking a question that you might feel is stupid, or you'll get laughed at over, or you should know the answer to) and he said, "where's meghan"? i'm meghan. i'm the only meghan he knows. i'm the only meghan in our family. there is no other meghan. my brain was a bit slow on the uptake because i was distracted by this stupid dinosaur pattern so without even looking up i just said, "you mean me?" and he goes, "oh, there you are!" and kinda chuckled. but over the 20 minutes that have followed, it's really hit me. my dad just asked where i was when i was sitting in plain sight of him. did he forget my name? did he not recognize me? why did he ask it the way he did? is this temporary or is this our new normal? (my dad tends to have good days and bad days, maybe this is just bad days and he'll get better soon?)  i'm having a hard time with it. part of me is freaking out because my dad forgot who i was. part of me almost doesn't care because my dad and i aren't exactly close and i grew up with him largely not in my life so the emotional attachment is almost nil. i cried for a few minutes but i'm not sure why. having a hard time understanding my emotions surrounding this. hopefully he doesn't forget who my son is anytime soon, those two are like best buds.

he's gotten noticeably worse the past few days.
there is no other meghan.
and kinda chuckled.
but over the 20 minutes that have followed, it's really hit me.
did he not recognize me?
why did he ask it the way he did?
part of me is freaking out because my dad forgot who i was.
part of me almost doesn't care because my dad and i aren't exactly close and i grew up with him largely not in my life so the emotional attachment is almost nil.
hopefully he doesn't forget who my son is anytime soon, those two are like best buds.

context: i guess i should have seen this coming. he's gotten noticeably worse the past few days. i think it was 3 days ago that he asked me if i'd fed the kids yet (i only have one child and he's an adult that makes his own meals most the time). later that day he asked me if i'd seen my daughter lately (i've never had a daughter, or anyone like a daughter to me, or anything like that). today dad and i were sitting in the living room. him on the couch snuggled with the dog watching bowling on tv. me in the chair next to the couch, fervently crocheting a stuffed dinosaur for a sick friend of mine. he started to speak, and you could tell in his voice that he almost didn't want to ask the question (you know that feeling you get when you're asking a question that you might feel is stupid, or you'll get laughed at over, or you should know the answer to) and he said, "where's meghan"? i'm meghan. i'm the only meghan he knows. i'm the only meghan in our family. there is no other meghan. my brain was a bit slow on the uptake because i was distracted by this stupid dinosaur pattern so without even looking up i just said, "you mean me?" and he goes, "oh, there you are!" and kinda chuckled. but over the 20 minutes that have followed, it's really hit me. my dad just asked where i was when i was sitting in plain sight of him. did he forget my name? did he not recognize me? why did he ask it the way he did? is this temporary or is this our new normal? (my dad tends to have good days and bad days, maybe this is just bad days and he'll get better soon?)  i'm having a hard time with it. part of me is freaking out because my dad forgot who i was. part of me almost doesn't care because my dad and i aren't exactly close and i grew up with him largely not in my life so the emotional attachment is almost nil. i cried for a few minutes but i'm not sure why. having a hard time understanding my emotions surrounding this. hopefully he doesn't forget who my son is anytime soon, those two are like best buds.

qas.question: i really would like to move out in may, but is that selfish of me?

answers.text: this might be a little bit of a long post, but all this has been really stressful to figure out and i'm hoping for some advice.
my mom just turned 73 and my dad 67. my mom's physical and mental health has slowly been declining in recent years.
we took in my grandma with alzheimer's back when i was 16, so i definitely know the toll that care giving can take and i don't feel like i'm prepared for my parents in the slightest.
flash forward to the present, and i have a great full-time position in my field and am graduating with my associate's in may.
i've been looking around for apartments to rent and was approved for a one in a great neighborhood that i can afford.
the only issue is the move in date isn't till september.
my friend said i could move in with her until then, but my mom wants me to stay with them for another 6 months.
they've been some of the most amazing people i've ever known, but my mom and i's relationship has been deteriorating fast.
i feel like every time we talk it turns into an argument.
even more now that she knows i'm getting ready to move out.
i don't intend to leave my parents to fend for themselves.
i've already been making plans to still be there for them as much as i can, but my mom keeps acting like she doesn't believe me.
i currently am working remotely, so i can even work from their place as needed to provide extra help.
i just don't know if it's going to be enough.
my dad's health isn't in the best shape either and i feel immensely guilty and selfish about the whole situation.
should i stay till september?
this might be a little bit of a long post, but all this has been really stressful to figure out and i'm hoping for some advice.
i'm sure many people here are going through similar situations, so i appreciate the help!
i'm a 23f who was adopted by my parents when they were in their 50s.
she's always been a very independent person and doesn't want any outside help (doctor, therapist, caregiver service, etc...) so my dad and i have been doing everything for her.
even so, her body is in a lot of pain and she frequently lashes out at us, which is especially hard since some of her pain could be eased if she'd go to a doctor.
we took in my grandma with alzheimer's back when i was 16, so i definitely know the toll that care giving can take and i don't feel like i'm prepared for my parents in the slightest.
a couple years ago, i promised my mom that i wouldn't move out till i got a degree and was financially stable.
the only issue is the move in date isn't till september.
my friend said i could move in with her until then, but my mom wants me to stay with them for another 6 months.
now i love my parents.
she deals with massive anxiety and has been getting more controlling the closer i get to moving out.
some of the stuff she tells me has been really hurtful and it's getting harder for me to be around her.
i know she's in a lot of pain, but i wish she wouldn't lash out so much.
i feel like every time we talk it turns into an argument.
i've already been making plans to still be there for them as much as i can, but my mom keeps acting like she doesn't believe me.

context: this might be a little bit of a long post, but all this has been really stressful to figure out and i'm hoping for some advice. i'm sure many people here are going through similar situations, so i appreciate the help! i'm a 23f who was adopted by my parents when they were in their 50s. my mom just turned 73 and my dad 67. my mom's physical and mental health has slowly been declining in recent years. she hasn't left the house since 2018 and has just started using a walker. she's always been a very independent person and doesn't want any outside help (doctor, therapist, caregiver service, etc...) so my dad and i have been doing everything for her. she seems to be in some denial about her condition and keeps tell us that she's getting better. even so, her body is in a lot of pain and she frequently lashes out at us, which is especially hard since some of her pain could be eased if she'd go to a doctor. we took in my grandma with alzheimer's back when i was 16, so i definitely know the toll that care giving can take and i don't feel like i'm prepared for my parents in the slightest. a couple years ago, i promised my mom that i wouldn't move out till i got a degree and was financially stable. flash forward to the present, and i have a great full-time position in my field and am graduating with my associate's in may. i'm planning to continue with online college in july to get my bachelor's. i've been looking around for apartments to rent and was approved for a one in a great neighborhood that i can afford. the only issue is the move in date isn't till september. my friend said i could move in with her until then, but my mom wants me to stay with them for another 6 months.  now i love my parents. they've been some of the most amazing people i've ever known, but my mom and i's relationship has been deteriorating fast. she deals with massive anxiety and has been getting more controlling the closer i get to moving out. some of the stuff she tells me has been really hurtful and it's getting harder for me to be around her. i know she's in a lot of pain, but i wish she wouldn't lash out so much. i feel like every time we talk it turns into an argument. even more now that she knows i'm getting ready to move out. she's been really hostile about the whole situation, says that i don't care about them, and am abandoning them.  i don't intend to leave my parents to fend for themselves. i've already been making plans to still be there for them as much as i can, but my mom keeps acting like she doesn't believe me. i plan on helping them on my days off by cleaning, getting groceries, and giving my dad a break. i currently am working remotely, so i can even work from their place as needed to provide extra help. i just don't know if it's going to be enough. my dad's health isn't in the best shape either and i feel immensely guilty and selfish about the whole situation. i know when things get worse i'll eventually have to move back in, but i just want a chance to live my own life for a little bit. i really would like to move out in may, but is that selfish of me? should i stay till september?

qas.question: does this group have any suggestions on how i can support my mom?

answers.text: my dad (71) has had ms for about 50 years and my mom has been his caregiver for their entire marriage.
my younger sister and i do not live in the area so try to find ways to support when we can, but arent able to provide consistent in person help.
the amount of care thats hes needed has increased over the years and our mom has been his full time caregiver for the last 10 years or so.
for now they dont have any in home nursing, but i could see that changing soon.
long story short, his health is really declining from not being at home and under my moms care.
hes getting good care at the rehab facility, but they arent as attentive as my mom is.
seeing my dad go through this and deteriorate is becoming very difficult for my mom and im not sure how to support her from afar.
my dads health is in the hands of the doctors and nurses, but i worry about who is taking care of my mom.
also if there are any books that are recommended for this situation, id be so appreciative.
the amount of care thats hes needed has increased over the years and our mom has been his full time caregiver for the last 10 years or so.
she has some hobbies that are therapeutic for her, but she doesnt go to therapy or have many other confidants to process everything that is going on with my dads illness.
my dad  had a terrible fall a few weeks ago that required a long surgery and a few weeks of staying in a rehab facility.
hes getting good care at the rehab facility, but they arent as attentive as my mom is.
thanks for reading.

context: apologies this is so long... i just dont know how to be concise about this.  my dad (71) has had ms for about 50 years and my mom has been his caregiver for their entire marriage. my younger sister and i do not live in the area so try to find ways to support when we can, but arent able to provide consistent in person help. the amount of care thats hes needed has increased over the years and our mom has been his full time caregiver for the last 10 years or so. she has always shied away from taking good care of herself because she has always put my dads needs first. she has some hobbies that are therapeutic for her, but she doesnt go to therapy or have many other confidants to process everything that is going on with my dads illness. for now they dont have any in home nursing, but i could see that changing soon.  my dad  had a terrible fall a few weeks ago that required a long surgery and a few weeks of staying in a rehab facility. long story short, his health is really declining from not being at home and under my moms care. hes getting good care at the rehab facility, but they arent as attentive as my mom is. on top of that hes dealt with some hospital psychosis which has just been so heart breaking.  seeing my dad go through this and deteriorate is becoming very difficult for my mom and im not sure how to support her from afar. i would fly down to visit, but im recovering from hip surgery and cant travel for another month. we talk about everyday or every other day and shes needed to verbally process more and more.  ive told her i am able to be a listening ear but i dont have the tools a therapist would have to really help. i cant imagine how hard it is for my mom (my heart hurts for her so much), but im starting to feel like i am out of my depth. i brought up finding a therapist again and she finally seemed receptive to it.  does this group have any suggestions on how i can support my mom? my dads health is in the hands of the doctors and nurses, but i worry about who is taking care of my mom. also if there are any books that are recommended for this situation, id be so appreciative. thanks for reading.

qas.question: but how do we know when she has gone from the pre-active stage to the active stage of death?

answers.text: so i'm not really here for any specific advice or anything, although comments and stories are more than welcome.

they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix.
back in august the doctors noticed that the cancer was starting to grow even while on chemo.
never eating a ton, but some days a few bites here and there.
we now know that this was likely the beginning of the pre-active phase of dying.

she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.
this isn't even to mention the super swollen legs from clots that she is having, the skin mottling, etc.
her main hospice nurse told us to be prepared because she could go at any time, but it could also be a couple of more weeks because she is a fighter who seems to be hanging on for family.
the waiting game.
how far away is that day?
thanks a lot.
xo

my grandma, who is sort of like a second mother to me, got diagnosed with stage 4 terminal ovarian cancer back in september 2018. at the time of finding it, it had already grown and spread far too much to ever be able to completely remove it or cure her.

they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix.
she was only 63 at the time and was not at all ready to go, so she chose chemo.
because of that me, my mom, my aunt, and her ex husband (my grandfather) stepped in to rotate as full time caregivers for now two and a half years.

since then it's been a bit of back and forth between a few days of being really, really bad.... no eating, sleeping a ton, wanting to be left along, and then she will randomly come out of it for a day or two and come back and sit in the living room or on her patio and be more herself.

she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.
this is what is killing me most.
the wondering if today will be the day.
how long does she have?
it's so mentally exhausting.

context: so i'm not really here for any specific advice or anything, although comments and stories are more than welcome. my grandma, who is sort of like a second mother to me, got diagnosed with stage 4 terminal ovarian cancer back in september 2018. at the time of finding it, it had already grown and spread far too much to ever be able to completely remove it or cure her. they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix. she was only 63 at the time and was not at all ready to go, so she chose chemo. also, around the time of diagnosis she started having neuropathy due to a stroke that they think was related to the cancer. so not only was she dying from the cancer, but basically overnight she lost all mobility and freedom. she couldn't walk or do anything alone. because of that me, my mom, my aunt, and her ex husband (my grandfather) stepped in to rotate as full time caregivers for now two and a half years. back in august the doctors noticed that the cancer was starting to grow even while on chemo. they had done many different types of chemotherapies to try and give her more time, and basically, the way it was told to us, was that her body sort of became immune to all of them and the cancer was beginning to outsmart the medicine, therefore, her "extra time" via chemo was coming to an end. she stopped the chemo in early august of 2020. from then until now we have all noticed a slow decline in her health, her mobility, etc etc. but the past month it has really gone downhill. march 15th and 16th were the first two days we really noticed drastic difference. those two days she stopped asking for her morning coffee, stopped eating often, and began sleeping a whole lot. since then it's been a bit of back and forth between a few days of being really, really bad.... no eating, sleeping a ton, wanting to be left along, and then she will randomly come out of it for a day or two and come back and sit in the living room or on her patio and be more herself. never eating a ton, but some days a few bites here and there. we now know that this was likely the beginning of the pre-active phase of dying. she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.  today she had a really bad morning, and for the first time seemed more incoherent than usual.  saying things that don't make a lot of sense, speaking about/to somebody named robert who none of my family or i know of, even reaching her hands out to the foot of her bed, saying "now?" in a happy tone with bright eyes.  this isn't even to mention the super swollen legs from clots that she is having, the skin mottling, etc. basically, we know these are all signs of impending death. but how do we know when she has gone from the pre-active stage to the active stage of death? her main hospice nurse told us to be prepared because she could go at any time, but it could also be a couple of more weeks because she is a fighter who seems to be hanging on for family. this is what is killing me most. the waiting game. the wondering if today will be the day. how far away is that day? how long does she have? it's so mentally exhausting. i'd love for anybody to share any advice or knowledge they may have or stories from dealing with the pre-active and active stages of dying. thanks a lot. xo

qas.question: how far away is that day?

answers.text: so i'm not really here for any specific advice or anything, although comments and stories are more than welcome.

they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix.
back in august the doctors noticed that the cancer was starting to grow even while on chemo.
never eating a ton, but some days a few bites here and there.
we now know that this was likely the beginning of the pre-active phase of dying.

she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.
this isn't even to mention the super swollen legs from clots that she is having, the skin mottling, etc.
but how do we know when she has gone from the pre-active stage to the active stage of death?
her main hospice nurse told us to be prepared because she could go at any time, but it could also be a couple of more weeks because she is a fighter who seems to be hanging on for family.
the waiting game.
thanks a lot.
xo

my grandma, who is sort of like a second mother to me, got diagnosed with stage 4 terminal ovarian cancer back in september 2018. at the time of finding it, it had already grown and spread far too much to ever be able to completely remove it or cure her.

they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix.
she was only 63 at the time and was not at all ready to go, so she chose chemo.
because of that me, my mom, my aunt, and her ex husband (my grandfather) stepped in to rotate as full time caregivers for now two and a half years.

since then it's been a bit of back and forth between a few days of being really, really bad.... no eating, sleeping a ton, wanting to be left along, and then she will randomly come out of it for a day or two and come back and sit in the living room or on her patio and be more herself.

she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.
this is what is killing me most.
the wondering if today will be the day.
it's so mentally exhausting.

context: so i'm not really here for any specific advice or anything, although comments and stories are more than welcome. my grandma, who is sort of like a second mother to me, got diagnosed with stage 4 terminal ovarian cancer back in september 2018. at the time of finding it, it had already grown and spread far too much to ever be able to completely remove it or cure her. they told us that she could either just live until it takes her (and at this time, they told us that would probably be 2-6 months) or she could do chemo to shrink the cancer and give her more time, but again, it would never be a cure or a fix. she was only 63 at the time and was not at all ready to go, so she chose chemo. also, around the time of diagnosis she started having neuropathy due to a stroke that they think was related to the cancer. so not only was she dying from the cancer, but basically overnight she lost all mobility and freedom. she couldn't walk or do anything alone. because of that me, my mom, my aunt, and her ex husband (my grandfather) stepped in to rotate as full time caregivers for now two and a half years. back in august the doctors noticed that the cancer was starting to grow even while on chemo. they had done many different types of chemotherapies to try and give her more time, and basically, the way it was told to us, was that her body sort of became immune to all of them and the cancer was beginning to outsmart the medicine, therefore, her "extra time" via chemo was coming to an end. she stopped the chemo in early august of 2020. from then until now we have all noticed a slow decline in her health, her mobility, etc etc. but the past month it has really gone downhill. march 15th and 16th were the first two days we really noticed drastic difference. those two days she stopped asking for her morning coffee, stopped eating often, and began sleeping a whole lot. since then it's been a bit of back and forth between a few days of being really, really bad.... no eating, sleeping a ton, wanting to be left along, and then she will randomly come out of it for a day or two and come back and sit in the living room or on her patio and be more herself. never eating a ton, but some days a few bites here and there. we now know that this was likely the beginning of the pre-active phase of dying. she has been in at home hospice since august when she ended chemo, and they have been incredibly helpful through all of this, educating us on the process of dying and trying to prepare us mentally and physically as best they can, but it has just been such an emotional rollercoaster with no real answers.  today she had a really bad morning, and for the first time seemed more incoherent than usual.  saying things that don't make a lot of sense, speaking about/to somebody named robert who none of my family or i know of, even reaching her hands out to the foot of her bed, saying "now?" in a happy tone with bright eyes.  this isn't even to mention the super swollen legs from clots that she is having, the skin mottling, etc. basically, we know these are all signs of impending death. but how do we know when she has gone from the pre-active stage to the active stage of death? her main hospice nurse told us to be prepared because she could go at any time, but it could also be a couple of more weeks because she is a fighter who seems to be hanging on for family. this is what is killing me most. the waiting game. the wondering if today will be the day. how far away is that day? how long does she have? it's so mentally exhausting. i'd love for anybody to share any advice or knowledge they may have or stories from dealing with the pre-active and active stages of dying. thanks a lot. xo

qas.question: what do i do?

answers.text: my job and social life.
i'm trying to get him on medicaid he has really bad trust issues and doesn't want to give me his information.
he has food stamps but refuses to put food in the house.
receives money from the government but doesn't want to put a dime toward anything he wants i pay for everything out of pocket food, clothes everything.
he will demand me to ask my boyfriend for money for things for my house but my boyfriend does not live with us.... my family has offered to help.

if i can't get him on medicaid i can't afford any type of assistance for him and i want to know what i can do legally to get my father out of my house at this point i don't care where he goes he still has his apartment he pays rent for.

i told him his 3 living options were assistant living, his apartment or another family member and he wants assisted living but i can't get information out of him to apply and he can't apply on his own.

he is currently on in house hospice and they won't take him into a facility unless he is deteriorating at an alarming rate.... for whatever reason he does not trust his family he has also told me he does not trust me i feel like he is only here because the hospital told him he needed someone to take care of him.
other family members have offered to house him to feed him and to help him but he refuses.
i understand he is terminally ill but i am only 27 and i dropped everything for him.
he will demand me to ask my boyfriend for money for things for my house but my boyfriend does not live with us.... my family has offered to help.
he told me he doesn't want to go back to his apartment but he keeps paying right there and he keeps it.
my father stop being active in my life after i turned 18 i am currently 27. what should i do?
but he doesn't want anyone else is help in i will be homeless trying to take care of him.

context: i am currently taking care of my father who doesn't want help of any family members other than my mother who doesn't stay longer than 2 hr for once or twice a week. parents are divorced.  i understand he is terminally ill but i am only 27 and i dropped everything for him. my job and social life.  i'm trying to get him on medicaid he has really bad trust issues and doesn't want to give me his information.  he has food stamps but refuses to put food in the house. receives money from the government but doesn't want to put a dime toward anything he wants i pay for everything out of pocket food, clothes everything.  he will demand me to ask my boyfriend for money for things for my house but my boyfriend does not live with us.... my family has offered to help. refuses to wear the clothing his family has gotten him because i am running low on money. if i can't get him on medicaid i can't afford any type of assistance for him and i want to know what i can do legally to get my father out of my house at this point i don't care where he goes he still has his apartment he pays rent for.   he told me he doesn't want to go back to his apartment but he keeps paying right there and he keeps it. i told him his 3 living options were assistant living, his apartment or another family member and he wants assisted living but i can't get information out of him to apply and he can't apply on his own.  he is currently on in house hospice and they won't take him into a facility unless he is deteriorating at an alarming rate.... for whatever reason he does not trust his family he has also told me he does not trust me i feel like he is only here because the hospital told him he needed someone to take care of him. my father stop being active in my life after i turned 18 i am currently 27. what should i do? i don't want to be evil and drop him off at his apartment for him to struggle and suffer alone. but he doesn't want anyone else is help in i will be homeless trying to take care of him. other family members have offered to house him to feed him and to help him but he refuses.  i have started relapsing in things that i have recovered in, i have been fighting with my friends and boyfriend and i've been very unhealthy to myself because my mental health is deteriorating. i can no longer stomach this.......my life is falling apart. what do i do?

answers.text: i was appalled at what i saw today.
first, i found out that every person in that facility has had covid.
thankfully im vaccinated but you would think thats something to disclose.
another resident doesnt speak english or understand english, and not one person makes an effort to use google translate to talk to them.
nothing!!!
first, i found out that every person in that facility has had covid.
thankfully im vaccinated but you would think thats something to disclose.
they walk around trying desperately to communicate and they cant.
lastly, there is one resident who is dying, no comfort is offered to them, they spent the whole day alone in their room.

context: ive been a caregiver for 3 years now. and i just started working at a facility with people who have dementia. i was appalled at what i saw today. first, i found out that every person in that facility has had covid. i had no idea. thankfully im vaccinated but you would think thats something to disclose. a resident urinated on the floor and no one cleaned it up. one resident has a dog and they allow the dog to pee and poop all over their room, the smell is so horrific i gagged when they opened the door. another resident doesnt speak english or understand english, and not one person makes an effort to use google translate to talk to them. they walk around trying desperately to communicate and they cant. lastly, there is one resident who is dying, no comfort is offered to them, they spent the whole day alone in their room. i am disgusted and i dont want to work here. i mean they dont even have books, magazines, or puzzles!!!! nothing!!! just todays hits playing. should i quit???

answers.text: its officially been 1 year and reality couldnt be more different.
the first 6-8 weeks were smooth.
it was ~105f outside and not a necessary chore.
i told him to leave it be or call my dad since he did all of the outside property maintenance for my grandparents.
we tried communicating.
he refused so we set our boundaries and stuck to them.
our relationship has turned into a business transaction.
nothing else.
my husband is fed up and angry.
my parents tell me hes always had a nasty side but since i never saw i didnt believe it would happen to us.
i feel like i let my husband down.
my grandpa says hes lonely a lot.
my parents visit 4x a week but thats not enough.
its just bad feelings all around.
maybe im not the only one struggling with someone like this.
its officially been 1 year and reality couldnt be more different.
i learned to cook his favorite recipes from scratch.
i made sure the house smelled nice and the atmosphere was comfortable.
i would have coffee with at the butt crack of dawn every morning.
he had just lost my grandma (married 63 years).
there was a tiny tree far out on his property that he wanted cut down.
i cannot stress how small this tree was.
quickly after that his true personality came out.
he tried more manipulation.
that pissed him off more.
if you made it this far thank you for listening.

context: i honestly thought id be a pro at this caregiving thing. i was a happy stay at home mom and a great house keeper before falling into this role. i thought it would be natural transition. its officially been 1 year and reality couldnt be more different.  the first 6-8 weeks were smooth. i was honored to care for my grandpa in his old age. i would play relaxing music and watch his westerns with him every night until he got tired. i learned to cook his favorite recipes from scratch. i made sure the house smelled nice and the atmosphere was comfortable. i would have coffee with at the butt crack of dawn every morning. he had just lost my grandma (married 63 years). i didnt want him to be lonely.  i still remember the day things got rocky 8 weeks in. there was a tiny tree far out on his property that he wanted cut down. he said he heard it cracking and popping as if it would fall. it was dead but it had been dead for years. i cannot stress how small this tree was. nobody in the house was in danger. nobody went near this tree. it was ~105f outside and not a necessary chore. i told him no. i told him to leave it be or call my dad since he did all of the outside property maintenance for my grandparents. he threw a fit and told me i must want my child dead. that it would fall on her and put her in a coma. he got attitude id never seen before. called me a negligent mother and told my husband he was lazy for not cutting it down.  we were floored.  quickly after that his true personality came out. he tried more manipulation. he became nosy and intrusive. started picking us apart for our beliefs, weight, choices...literally anything. he said if he was miserable he wanted everyone around him to be miserable too. we tried communicating. he refused so we set our boundaries and stuck to them. that pissed him off more. slowly i stopped spending so much free time with him since all he did was talk down to us.  our relationship has turned into a business transaction. i cook, clean, pay his bills, and take him to appointments. nothing else. there is no grandfather/granddaughter relationship anymore. i no longer have coffee with him. no longer watch his westerns or make and effort outside of his normal care. his nasty attitude has stuck since that day the tree almost fell.  my husband is fed up and angry. hes works long hours and goes to college at night. he wants to get the hell out of here but were stuck until he graduates in 2022. im upset that my grandpa is not the man i thought he was. my parents tell me hes always had a nasty side but since i never saw i didnt believe it would happen to us. they warned me and i ignored them. i thought bc our relationship was different this would be easy. clearly thats not the case.  i feel like i let my husband down. i feel like this  toxic household is my fault. maybe if i tired harder wed still be living here peacefully? my grandpa says hes lonely a lot. my parents visit 4x a week but thats not enough. i told him wed spend more leisure time with him when he stopped crossing boundaries. he denies he has attitude so we continue to stay in our bed room separate from him (once hes been fed and cared for of course). its just bad feelings all around. i hate it so much.  anyway. if you made it this far thank you for listening. it feels good to let this stuff out sometimes. maybe im not the only one struggling with someone like this.

qas.question: i have guilt because of how much i resent them, i know alot of it isnt their fault lord knows my grandmother has reasons to be miserable but how is it fair to me, to take someone who has to take medication just to be touched, now cleaning, wiping, bathing other people and getting more depressed because i'm told how much of a fuck up i am the entire time?

answers.text: i'm going to sound heartless and i am but i have no relationship with this woman prior, my mother took care of her for a couple years until she died suddenly of cancer and prior to that my mother hated the woman because of how she treated her, she only reconciled because my grandmother had a stroke and no one to take care of her.

this isnt the life i envisioned, i wont even have time to listen to music with headphones or leave to do boring errands, my life will be devoted to taking care of a miserable woman who treats me like crap all day.
everyone i reached out to agreed.
i'm in my late 20s stuck taking care of my elderly disabled grandmother and i hate it.

i'm going to sound heartless and i am but i have no relationship with this woman prior, my mother took care of her for a couple years until she died suddenly of cancer and prior to that my mother hated the woman because of how she treated her, she only reconciled because my grandmother had a stroke and no one to take care of her.
there's even some resentment, although unfairly, because this woman stole the last few years with my mother who was my best friend.

this isnt the life i envisioned, i wont even have time to listen to music with headphones or leave to do boring errands, my life will be devoted to taking care of a miserable woman who treats me like crap all day.
i can't leave either, i'm mentally disabled with a chronic illness, you can't live on your own, i'm stuck.

context: i'm in my late 20s stuck taking care of my elderly disabled grandmother and i hate it. i'm going to sound heartless and i am but i have no relationship with this woman prior, my mother took care of her for a couple years until she died suddenly of cancer and prior to that my mother hated the woman because of how she treated her, she only reconciled because my grandmother had a stroke and no one to take care of her. there's even some resentment, although unfairly, because this woman stole the last few years with my mother who was my best friend. she made my father promise to take care of my gram, and naturally like everything my father pushed it onto me (he's abusive and loves the bottle more) i take care of all her needs from small stuff like changing tv channels to big stuff like bathing and feeding her. she has gastritis she ignores and eats food that makes her shit everywhere and i'm left to clean it up, i asked doctors and they shrug and say since shes in her right mind and what not, i cant deprive her of what she wants. i tried cooking her a diet that works with the illness and she flat out wont eat and sulks. she's miserable to be around she sucks the life out of you, every time i sit with her she brings up my dead mother, my life failures, my dog that will be dead soon, yell at me for not doing things i'm supposed to (cant, i have to watch her). she recently had a fall because up until then she was walking fine but she likes to turn and plop down onto things expecting she's fine, she did it when she lived alone she just doesnt pay attention. now rehab says she's the best she'll be meaning i not only have to wash, bathe, and do everything else but that i'll have to stay on-call 24/7 for when she has to get up and hold her gait belt, i even have to get a buzzer for when she needs to get up at 3 am to go. not to mention she'll be making "messes" constantly.  this isnt the life i envisioned, i wont even have time to listen to music with headphones or leave to do boring errands, my life will be devoted to taking care of a miserable woman who treats me like crap all day. i can't leave either, i'm mentally disabled with a chronic illness, you can't live on your own, i'm stuck. everyone i reached out to agreed. it's just a miserable situation that everyone seems fine passing the buck off to me because "i'm family". best part? my father is going blind soon, so i'll have 2 seniors to take care of.  i have guilt because of how much i resent them, i know alot of it isnt their fault lord knows my grandmother has reasons to be miserable but how is it fair to me, to take someone who has to take medication just to be touched, now cleaning, wiping, bathing other people and getting more depressed because i'm told how much of a fuck up i am the entire time?

qas.question: secondly, does anyone have any advice or knowledge about assisted living when on either plan?

answers.text: hey all, firstly i want to show some love to all us caregivers doing the hardest job we've ever loved.
she can do some thing independently and i'm totally willing to help her as i can.
do her laundry, cook, shop for her, help her shower; but a nursing home will take a huge chunk of her quality of life away.
she's only 65 and i really feel that she would be completely miserable there.
i'm exhausted and truly can't see my life getting any better financially, emotionally or mentally; than hers if things stay this way .
she just needs more and i'm lost on how to help.
do her laundry, cook, shop for her, help her shower; but a nursing home will take a huge chunk of her quality of life away.
i'm 31 and have been by her side for the last 5 years.
she just needs more and i'm lost on how to help.
does going to a facility mean she loses her ssdi, car (as just an asset), life insurance and bank account?

context: hey all, firstly i want to show some love to all us caregivers doing the hardest job we've ever loved. shout out to the strength and vulnerability we all share here.  secondly, does anyone have any advice or knowledge about assisted living when on either plan? my mom is declining rapidly and it's to the point that instead of living with me, i'm taking more care of her than i can handle as an only child working 15 hour days.  she can do some thing independently and i'm totally willing to help her as i can. do her laundry, cook, shop for her, help her shower; but a nursing home will take a huge chunk of her quality of life away. she's only 65 and i really feel that she would be completely miserable there. we've had terrible experiences in nursing homes when she's gone for rehab from injuries and i really fear about that happening again. she's not one to speak up much because she "doesn't want to get anyone in trouble"  however, i need my life back. i'm 31 and have been by her side for the last 5 years. i'm exhausted and truly can't see my life getting any better financially, emotionally or mentally; than hers if things stay this way . she just needs more and i'm lost on how to help. does going to a facility mean she loses her ssdi, car (as just an asset), life insurance and bank account? i don't want her to feel like everything has been "taken" from her because she truly is an angel and has worked so hard for so long to achieve goals.  thank you for any and all help, i appreciate everyone!
