qas.question: what else can i do to make it a better job?

answers.text: i finally got assigned a caregiver.
unfortunately she is underpaid and i dont really know what to do about that.
theres strict rules against supplementing the pay and i dont want to get kicked off the program so i have to wait till i know her before i can do anything like that.
i thought of maybe writing a list of what all needs to get done, but i dont know if this would seem too bossy or not.

i also though of writing a list of things that might be useful to know about me, just cause i have periods of being nonverbal and though it might be useful, like what all i generally need help with and what symptoms are normal and not to worry about (like sometimes people think i'm having a seizure when i'm not).
but i dont know if this will seem too pushy or weird.
i dont know, i dont want to come on too strong, but i want to do whatever i can to make things as easy as possible.
i'm also super flexible with scheduling.

really i'm thinking of just letting her know what my awake hours are and letting her know she can work whenever she wants as long as we get the basics taken care of (like bathing twice a week- but any time or day is fone as long as it's a few days apart).
i dont know what the hardest part of caregiving is, besides the lousy pay.
any input would be appreciated.
sorry if this is the wrong sub, i wasn't sure where something like this would get responses.
unfortunately she is underpaid and i dont really know what to do about that.
i have 18 hours a week and i probably only need like 10 so they will have lots of downtime or can work at whatever pace they want.
i'm getting some help to detail my house so it's super clean and organized when she starts.
i dont know, i dont want to come on too strong, but i want to do whatever i can to make things as easy as possible.
people have a hard time keeping caregivers that arent family or friends so i want this person to have the best job possible.
i'm also super flexible with scheduling.

really i'm thinking of just letting her know what my awake hours are and letting her know she can work whenever she wants as long as we get the basics taken care of (like bathing twice a week- but any time or day is fone as long as it's a few days apart).

context: i finally got assigned a caregiver. unfortunately she is underpaid and i dont really know what to do about that. theres strict rules against supplementing the pay and i dont want to get kicked off the program so i have to wait till i know her before i can do anything like that.  what else can i do to make it a better job? i have 18 hours a week and i probably only need like 10 so they will have lots of downtime or can work at whatever pace they want.  i'm getting some help to detail my house so it's super clean and organized when she starts.  i thought of maybe writing a list of what all needs to get done, but i dont know if this would seem too bossy or not.  i also though of writing a list of things that might be useful to know about me, just cause i have periods of being nonverbal and though it might be useful, like what all i generally need help with and what symptoms are normal and not to worry about (like sometimes people think i'm having a seizure when i'm not). but i dont know if this will seem too pushy or weird.  i dont know, i dont want to come on too strong, but i want to do whatever i can to make things as easy as possible. people have a hard time keeping caregivers that arent family or friends so i want this person to have the best job possible. i constantly work to become more independent, hopefully i will need her help less and less as time goes on.  i'm also super flexible with scheduling. really i'm thinking of just letting her know what my awake hours are and letting her know she can work whenever she wants as long as we get the basics taken care of (like bathing twice a week- but any time or day is fone as long as it's a few days apart).  i dont know what the hardest part of caregiving is, besides the lousy pay. i've even considered asking if she wants to work a few extra hours and then just pay her crazy good for that time to balance out the other hours, still waiting to hear back of that's allowed.  any input would be appreciated. sorry if this is the wrong sub, i wasn't sure where something like this would get responses.  tia

qas.question: here i am putting away the dinner and freezing some left overs, and the best you got is ive left the fridge door open  do you know how many times i tell my kids i love them?

answers.text: im 56m caring for my 83y old father.
tonight as im packing ham, from the fridge to the freezer.
tonight as im packing ham, from the fridge to the freezer.
he says, son you left the fridge door wide open as hes walking by from the restroom to his tv room having no clue what i was working on.
then i sort of exploded and said at 56 i can count on one hand the number of times youve passed me and said i love you.
no wonder why i have issues, been divorced twice and now living at home taking care of dad.

context: im 56m caring for my 83y old father.  tonight as im packing ham, from the fridge to the freezer.  he says, son you left the fridge door wide open as hes walking by from the restroom to his tv room having no clue what i was working on. then i sort of exploded and said at 56 i can count on one hand the number of times youve passed me and said i love you.  here i am putting away the dinner and freezing some left overs, and the best you got is ive left the fridge door open  do you know how many times i tell my kids i love them? he says i apologize but, i love you just isnt a word weve used around here ugh!!  no wonder why i have issues, been divorced twice and now living at home taking care of dad.

qas.question: what can i do to help my parents?

answers.text: my (40sf) dad (68m) was diagnosed last month with gbm, it's been a rollercoaster the last 3 weeks.
his agitation has eased somewhat, he's wobbly when he's walking, has no pain complaints, and we have hospice assistance in home 2x a week to help him bathe.
this is all unbelievably overwhelming for my mom, she's watching my dad worsen each day.
what support should i be giving my dad?
how can i support my mom?
thankfully we are neighbors, so that helps.
after the biopsy he was unable to walk or sit up on his own, his neurosurgeon directed us to place him in a nursing home.

he was discharged to a nursing home, they literally did not take care of his basic needs, he went without clean clothes for 3 days, no assistance to/from the bathroom, feeding, bathing, oral care for 5 days.
my mom (67f) and i got him out of there as fast as we could and he's now home.

context: my (40sf) dad (68m) was diagnosed last month with gbm, it's been a rollercoaster the last 3 weeks.   after the biopsy he was unable to walk or sit up on his own, his neurosurgeon directed us to place him in a nursing home.  he was discharged to a nursing home, they literally did not take care of his basic needs, he went without clean clothes for 3 days, no assistance to/from the bathroom, feeding, bathing, oral care for 5 days.   my mom (67f) and i got him out of there as fast as we could and he's now home.  his agitation has eased somewhat, he's wobbly when he's walking, has no pain complaints, and we have hospice assistance in home 2x a week to help him bathe.  i make most of the meals and take them over, do grocery runs, order necessities from amazon or buy in our local shop. this is all unbelievably overwhelming for my mom, she's watching my dad worsen each day.  glioblastoma is fast.  he was driving a month ago. what can i do to help my parents?  what support should i be giving my dad?  how can i support my mom?  thankfully we are neighbors, so that helps. :)

qas.question: is it just that see saw between what they can't do and what they can do that makes me upset?

answers.text: because not course i never mind helping them.
there are still things they can do for themselves but then there are parts they can't do and it seems to change everyday.
and i try to anticipate the problems and come up short.

context: any good online reads for learning how to deal with a dementia patient? perhaps there is no amount of reading that can better equip me. i just feel like i am constantly loosing my patience and every thing is a loosing battle. there are still things they can do for themselves but then there are parts they can't do and it seems to change everyday. and i try to anticipate the problems and come up short. it's unreasonable that i get so agitated every day when they put on their oxygen tube or when they keep turning the portable oxygen machine off. if they were in a wheelchair i would not get mad they can't walk. is it just that see saw between what they can't do and what they can do that makes me upset? because not course i never mind helping them.

qas.question: if any of you reading this have been in a similar boat, how did you motivate your loved one to get better?

answers.text: i feel like myself and my family are in a rock and a hard place.
she last saw the doctor for it in 2018 and hasnt been back since due to her mobility declining.
this is due to after she had her left hip replaced, she decided after 6 physical therapy sessions that she didnt need it anymore as well as exercises at hone and stopped everything.
shes also diabetic on top of everything else.
my dad is retired from his job and he saw them traveling together as well as moving to fl.
some days i dont think she wants to.
we all want to see her walking and be mobile again.
she has said she wants it as well but then also talks about being fine if shes destined to be in a motorized wheelchair.

i am worried that maybe her left hip is to far gone and theres nothing they can do being its been 3 years since its been looked at-but thats something you dont know until it comes to that and im not thinking that way right now.
any help or advice is appreciated more than you know.
thanks in advance.
this is due to after she had her left hip replaced, she decided after 6 physical therapy sessions that she didnt need it anymore as well as exercises at hone and stopped everything.
my dad has, naturally, a considerable amount of weight on him being her caregiver but it would be easier on him too if she did some things to help herself.
she has said she wants it as well but then also talks about being fine if shes destined to be in a motorized wheelchair.
any help or advice is appreciated more than you know.
thanks in advance.

context: i feel like myself and my family are in a rock and a hard place. my mom has been bed bound for the past few years due to a deteriorating left hip. she last saw the doctor for it in 2018 and hasnt been back since due to her mobility declining. this is due to after she had her left hip replaced, she decided after 6 physical therapy sessions that she didnt need it anymore as well as exercises at hone and stopped everything. this has caused her left hip to compensate and speed up the wear and tear on it and ultimately has now taken her mobility. she has had several sessions of home care and physical therapy come out and treat her but to keep her motivated to do what she needs to do to get better doesnt last long. shes also diabetic on top of everything else. she cant pivot to get out of bed and when she sits up, she complains thats shes lightheaded and dizzy, probably because shes been sitting in a certain position for so long. i think she may have congested heart failure and shes lost a considerable amount of muscle tone. i dont know what to do to help her and to see her like this, its so frustrating to just accept it and do nothing. my dad is retired from his job and he saw them traveling together as well as moving to fl. all of it is on hold until she gets better. some days i dont think she wants to.  my dad has, naturally, a considerable amount of weight on him being her caregiver but it would be easier on him too if she did some things to help herself. she just doesnt. if any of you reading this have been in a similar boat, how did you motivate your loved one to get better? we all want to see her walking and be mobile again. she has said she wants it as well but then also talks about being fine if shes destined to be in a motorized wheelchair. i am worried that maybe her left hip is to far gone and theres nothing they can do being its been 3 years since its been looked at-but thats something you dont know until it comes to that and im not thinking that way right now. any help or advice is appreciated more than you know. thanks in advance.

qas.question: are you glad you did it, would you do it again given the chance?

answers.text: summary: wife and i are in our early 30s, no kids but a few pets.
ive worked from home since the pandemic and my wife hasnt worked since a little bit after that.

she has a rough time at night due to sun downers, and has her kids over multiple times a day for small things like getting the tv working, whereas night time calls are more anxious like thinking theres someone at the window.
we offered to move in with her and help take care of meals, mobility, tech, etc.
but im worried sun downers may be too advanced for two newbies to properly help with.
im wondering if the change of us living there plus our pets and bringing our own stuff with might just make it worse.
thanks in advance.
summary: wife and i are in our early 30s, no kids but a few pets.
ive worked from home since the pandemic and my wife hasnt worked since a little bit after that.
so were home all the time anyway.
im wondering if the change of us living there plus our pets and bringing our own stuff with might just make it worse.
would appreciate any advice from people who have made this decision before.

context: summary: wife and i are in our early 30s, no kids but a few pets. ive worked from home since the pandemic and my wife hasnt worked since a little bit after that. so were home all the time anyway. my grandma is mid 80s, and has been living alone for a few years. she has a rough time at night due to sun downers, and has her kids over multiple times a day for small things like getting the tv working, whereas night time calls are more anxious like thinking theres someone at the window. we offered to move in with her and help take care of meals, mobility, tech, etc. but im worried sun downers may be too advanced for two newbies to properly help with.  were used to quiet evenings and know this will be a change but thought she would be happier in her own home vs an elder care facility. im wondering if the change of us living there plus our pets and bringing our own stuff with might just make it worse. would appreciate any advice from people who have made this decision before. are you glad you did it, would you do it again given the chance? any thoughts on the pet situation? theyre like our kids and we dont want to have to choose between them. thanks in advance.

she's dieing in front of me with nothing to do for it.
its so hard.
so income has reduced drastically.
not even with money although it would help.
but with managing all this stuff, or rides or help with grief.... i don't know... help with knowing what i need help with.
i'm 31 with 3 kids which obviously has its own stressor.
in the past year my mother who has had krohns for my whole life has also been diagnosed with duodenal cancer.
they cut out 2/3 of her stomach to try and avoid chemo, but it was unsuccessful.
now she has fistulas from surgery that refuse to heal so she can't start chemo or try any other operation.
so income has reduced drastically.
and i constantly feel like i'm neglecting my kids,wife, mom, grandmother,friend, and self because they all neeed so much.
and they all make me feel that way too.

im short and angry a lot so my wife gets mad and i just feel like i'm on the edge of a mental break.
like i'm just flooring it full speed through dense fog.

context: i'm 31 with 3 kids which obviously has its own stressor. in the past year my mother who has had krohns for my whole life has also been diagnosed with duodenal cancer. they cut out 2/3 of her stomach to try and avoid chemo, but it was unsuccessful. now she has fistulas from surgery that refuse to heal so she can't start chemo or try any other operation. she's dieing in front of me with nothing to do for it. its so hard. my grandmother has copd and dementia, that in the last two weeks has gotten much worse( the dementia). my mom has no license and my grandmother is in no state to drive. i drive them to all their appointments,pick up all the medicines , drive for surgery/appts/ etc 6 hours away somewhat frequently. since covid i got on unemployment and have stayed on it longer than i would have probably because they started to decline around the same time. so income has reduced drastically. on top of it my best friend has (i believe) undiagnosed schizophrenia or multiple personality disorder and wont get help/ believes he doesn5 need it, and i'm his main source of venting or aid when he needs it. and i constantly feel like i'm neglecting my kids,wife, mom, grandmother,friend, and self because they all neeed so much. and they all make me feel that way too.(besides kids). im short and angry a lot so my wife gets mad and i just feel like i'm on the edge of a mental break.( not suicidal at all, just...i don't know what i am)sorry this is so long, i just..... i feel like i'm going to break, i try so hard. i'm irritable, tired, stressed, depressed, and crumbling.....is there any kind of programs or anything that can help me? not even with money although it would help. but with managing all this stuff, or rides or help with grief.... i don't know... help with knowing what i need help with. thank you in advance for any suggestions. it's getting so bad i can't think straight and have trouble with everyday tasks that i normally do almost without thinking like make a transfer through online banking.  like i'm just flooring it full speed through dense fog.

qas.question: my question is: how often and to what extent do i offer help?

answers.text: my (35f) friend (55f) has been her husbands caregiver for about 3 months.
she has been an incredible mentor to me and is an absolute lynchpin for our workplace.
i have offered her my ear, to send or pick up food/groceries for her, money for home health care help, etc.
i know that having help (especially home health care) would ease her burden, but i dont want to be too pushy.
any ideas on what kind of help to offer, ways to show support, or resources would also be appreciated.
thanks!
if this is not the appropriate subreddit, please feel free to remove it.
he is not eligible for a transplant now and the treatment for the cancer will complicate his treatment for the liver disease.
my friend is devastated and exhausted, but she is incredibly independent and does not want to burden anyone with her problems.

she does not have any local family and neither her nor her husband have any family that is in a position to help with his care, so right now she is the sole caregiver and breadwinner for her husband (she is on leave from work right now).
we are extremely close friends and what shes going through breaks my heart.
i know that having help (especially home health care) would ease her burden, but i dont want to be too pushy.
thanks!

context: if this is not the appropriate subreddit, please feel free to remove it.  my (35f) friend (55f) has been her husbands caregiver for about 3 months. he has end stage liver disease, and while getting evaluated for a transplant, the doctors discovered he has a very aggressive form of cancer. he is not eligible for a transplant now and the treatment for the cancer will complicate his treatment for the liver disease.  my friend is devastated and exhausted, but she is incredibly independent and does not want to burden anyone with her problems. i understand completely how she feels, as she is a very selfless person who takes great pride in hard work. she does not have any local family and neither her nor her husband have any family that is in a position to help with his care, so right now she is the sole caregiver and breadwinner for her husband (she is on leave from work right now). she has been an incredible mentor to me and is an absolute lynchpin for our workplace. she is an eternal optimist and can find a silver lining in any situation, including the one shes in right now. but i (along with our coworkers) worry about her mental and emotional health during this incredibly challenging time. it would be enough to break the strongest person.  i have offered her my ear, to send or pick up food/groceries for her, money for home health care help, etc. i text and call her at least once a week to check on her, but she usually doesnt reply or pick up, which is absolutely fine. it is just out of character when we typically talk/text every day both at and away from work. our coworkers even refer to her as my work wife because we work so well and often with each other. we are extremely close friends and what shes going through breaks my heart.  i adore her and there is no favor she could ask that my family wouldnt do for her. i know that having help (especially home health care) would ease her burden, but i dont want to be too pushy. she is very isolated right now and even though i know she is a strong person and could get through everything alone if needed, she doesnt have to.  my question is: how often and to what extent do i offer help? i dont want to do anything that causes her more stress. any ideas on what kind of help to offer, ways to show support, or resources would also be appreciated. thanks!

qas.question: what does the state do for people who have no one to care for them?

answers.text: the problem is, is that i am moving out at the end of the summer.
this leaves us in a predicament where there is no one to care for my father at home, except for my little brother (and it would not be fair to put this burden on him.)
what are our options?
we live in utah and my father is 65. we cant afford an in home nurse on our own.
should i just resign myself to being stuck here forever?
so my father has parkinsons, he was diagnosed around 13 years ago and he also now has dementia as a result of his parkinsons.
i know these episodes will just get worse and longer as time goes on.
the problem is, is that i am moving out at the end of the summer.
i know its a bit selfish but i am 27 and i would like to start my own life.
my mother also has to continue working full time to pay the bills.
right now it seems like were in a never ending hell and its only going to get worse as his disease progresses.
what are our options?
we live in utah and my father is 65. we cant afford an in home nurse on our own.
are we just screwed?

context: so my father has parkinsons, he was diagnosed around 13 years ago and he also now has dementia as a result of his parkinsons. i have put my life on hold to help my mother take care of him and she has also sacrificed a lot to provide the care he needs. the last few years he has really declined and he has started to have episodes where he acts very confused, stumbles and falls, makes littles sense. i know these episodes will just get worse and longer as time goes on. the problem is, is that i am moving out at the end of the summer. i know its a bit selfish but i am 27 and i would like to start my own life. my mother also has to continue working full time to pay the bills. this leaves us in a predicament where there is no one to care for my father at home, except for my little brother (and it would not be fair to put this burden on him.) when my father was first diagnosed he made my mother promise that she wouldnt put him in a home, but i dont know if well be able to keep that promise as much as he doesnt want it. but even then we wouldnt be able to afford it? what does the state do for people who have no one to care for them? just let them rot? im so frustrated at this point. how are people supposed to work a full time job to pay the bills and caregive full time (for free). right now it seems like were in a never ending hell and its only going to get worse as his disease progresses. what are our options? we live in utah and my father is 65. we cant afford an in home nurse on our own.  are we just screwed? should i just resign myself to being stuck here forever?

there isn't much online about delayed side effects.
i'm interested in anyone's opinions.

yikes.

i'm going to call her doctor tomorrow to get their opinion.
i really hope she feels better tomorrow.
the pneumonia the doctor's thought was covid, but she tested negative 4 times.

context: my mom is 76 and has a ton of medical issues (the biggies though being strokes, heart attacks, high blood pressure, and now on oxygen since having pneumonia in december). she got the first pfizer vaccine 2 weeks ago. she had no side effects at first, except she did say her left arm (her bad stoke side, and not the arm she got the needle in) ached. 9 days in (4 days ago), she starts talking about joint pain in her right knee. 3 days ago the knee pain makes it hard for her to transfer to the bathroom on her own (the one thing left she must be able to do in her own). yesterday she became more fatigued than usual. today she gets super fatigued, a stomach ache, a mild (99.3) fever, and has chills. yikes. could this be super late vaccine aide effects? anyone else experiencing this? there isn't much online about delayed side effects. it makes me wonder if she should get the second shot. i'm going to call her doctor tomorrow to get their opinion. i really hope she feels better tomorrow. i'm interested in anyone's opinions. in case anyone asks, i do not know if she had covid before. the pneumonia the doctor's thought was covid, but she tested negative 4 times.

qas.question: any advice or lessons learned on setting clear expectations before diving into a short term care scenario?

answers.text: i've seen countless posts of folks who have unclear boundaries or who are burnt out after a time of caregiving.
a few details:  he is going through a spinal fusion, with an 8+ week recovery time.
my husband is not coming because my work can be remote and his cannot.
fil is single, lives alone in a small rural town that is not walkable.
i shared that i'm happy to take leave from work, starting with 3 weeks, to care for him full time and will extend as needed.
i don't think he'll need that help, but am nervous because he said he will not pay or take any professional care (part of why i offered to come out).
my fil is great, but i already have years of him expecting me to cook and clean when we're together, having high expectations and generally not thanking me.
i want this time to be one where he gets his needs met to recover, and his house taken care of, while i can feel good on the other side and not taken advantage of.
ultimately i love him and i am the best suited to come out and help him, so advice like don't do it is not what i'm after.
a few details:  he is going through a spinal fusion, with an 8+ week recovery time.
"the basement storage could really use organizing / a purge."
my fil is great, but i already have years of him expecting me to cook and clean when we're together, having high expectations and generally not thanking me.
ideally this is also an opportunity for us to get closer.

context: i've seen countless posts of folks who have unclear boundaries or who are burnt out after a time of caregiving.  i'm [34f] about a week out from starting to care for my fil [60 m], and would love advice on how to set expectations early on so we'll have a great relationship in the future.  a few details:  he is going through a spinal fusion, with an 8+ week recovery time.  i'll be driving in from out of state and living in his basement.  my husband is not coming because my work can be remote and his cannot. fil is single, lives alone in a small rural town that is not walkable.   i shared that i'm happy to take leave from work, starting with 3 weeks, to care for him full time and will extend as needed. after i'll  plan to work remote and stay at the house while splitting care once he seems on his feet. i still get my full pay and benefits for up to 5 months so this just makes sense.  we talked about me cleaning, cooking, laundry, driving him to appts, but i drew the line at wound dressing and bathing.  i don't think he'll need that help, but am nervous because he said he will not pay or take any professional care (part of why i offered to come out).  he's started hinting at bigger projects without yet asking: "oh, i wish your husband were coming i've really been meaning to finish the hardwood floors." "i'm putting together a list of sewing projects you can get done while you're here." "i'm hoping you can plant all my garden beds since it's april." "the basement storage could really use organizing / a purge."  my fil is great, but i already have years of him expecting me to cook and clean when we're together, having high expectations and generally not thanking me.  in normal times he is picky and demanding and critical, and doesn't acknowledge the work put in to please him.  i want this time to be one where he gets his needs met to recover, and his house taken care of, while i can feel good on the other side and not taken advantage of.  ultimately i love him and i am the best suited to come out and help him, so advice like don't do it is not what i'm after.   ideally this is also an opportunity for us to get closer.  any advice or lessons learned on setting clear expectations before diving into a short term care scenario?

qas.question: what do you do?

answers.text: my mother's husband is showing signs of cognitive decline.
he lost his meds, shoes, wallet, keys, phone, and watch and even called the police to make a report, strongly implying that i stole them.
he's also threatened to call the police on me for stealing these things then they inevitably show up somewhere that he left them.
he locks his room with a key, too so it's not like i could get in and he still accuses me.
i know it may sound insensitive but he's so combative at this point, or pretends not to hear or see you if he doesn't agree so there's really no other option.
he was manipulative and controlling even before all of this so i'm terrified about him being a danger.
my mother keeps saying 'not to worry about it'.
just.
my mother's husband is showing signs of cognitive decline.
like many i moved in with them at the beginning of covid and he blames everything that goes missing or wrong or that he forgets on me.
he locks his room with a key, too so it's not like i could get in and he still accuses me.
he refuses to get help, and today she got pissed off and told him to move out if he's going to keep accusing me of stuff.

context: my mother's husband is showing signs of cognitive decline. like many i moved in with them at the beginning of covid and he blames everything that goes missing or wrong or that he forgets on me.  he lost his meds, shoes, wallet, keys, phone, and watch and even called the police to make a report, strongly implying that i stole them. he's also threatened to call the police on me for stealing these things then they inevitably show up somewhere that he left them. it's literally every week and i'm fucking tired of it, and of being afraid for my and my mother's safety when he has a tantrum.  he locks his room with a key, too so it's not like i could get in and he still accuses me. i could leave but then i worry about leaving my mother and putting her at risk. he refuses to get help, and today she got pissed off and told him to move out if he's going to keep accusing me of stuff. she'll help with the downpayment for his own place, etc. i know it may sound insensitive but he's so combative at this point, or pretends not to hear or see you if he doesn't agree so there's really no other option.  he was manipulative and controlling even before all of this so i'm terrified about him being a danger. my mother keeps saying 'not to worry about it'. just. how do you deal? what do you do?

so my dad is 71 and had a couple strokes about 10 years back.
he and my mother have been married for 40 years and recently he has had growing delusions in which he thinks my mother has cheated on him.
his demeanor is usually very pleasant.
he's a very intelligent man but very stubborn.
can medications help dementia and reduce his delusions enough for them to find some harmony?
thanks

context: so my dad is 71 and had a couple strokes about 10 years back.  he and my mother have been married for 40 years and recently he has had growing delusions in which he thinks my mother has cheated on him. he will wake her up in the middle of the night and berate her with accusations of infidelity; stemming from the most inoculous incident (like a friendly greeting from another man).  the arguments will become very intense but not violent.  his demeanor is usually very pleasant.  no amount of logic will persuade him and my mother feels like divorce may be the only option. he's a very intelligent man but very stubborn.  he has seen a couple therapist from the va but thinks the don't know anything or that my mother has turned them against him. my questions are: does this sound like dementia or bi-polar syndrome?  can medications help dementia and reduce his delusions enough for them to find some harmony?  can bouts of the same reoccurring delusion ever be fully subdued through logic?   thanks

qas.question: anyway, am i overreacting or will this get worse as she gets older?

criticizing others or feeling like everyone is out to get her. she's started being less cautious about other drivers, insisting that she has the right of way and if she did get into an accident, she would be in the right. it's toxic to hear about how other drivers are terrible and she's the only person who knows how to operate a vehicle safely /s. example: today, mom and i ran errands and someone ran (or rolled) through a stop sign as we were making our way out of the parking lot (we did not have a stop sign and the guy was turning into the lane to get to the stores we went past). he didn't stop and she could see that. she clearly had enough time and space to stop, but even though the guy was clearly not stopping or even seemed to care about her 10 second horn toot, she kept moving forward as the other car was turning. she's not wrong, i guess, but it just seems really aggressive to me and sometimes being right is more trouble than it is worth. my mantra for driving is to drive defensively -- if i was driving, i would have stopped immediately after seeing he didn't. it's like my mom is more interested in being "right" as opposed to being safe. i honestly don't feel qas.question: at what point do you make the decisions for them?

answers.text: my dad lives across country with his girlfriend.
we noticed something was off about a year and a half ago.
i feel very selfish, but im sick of living on edge and not knowing what the next steps are.
i am so nervous ill lose my job over the constant back and forth.
when this it was explained to his girlfriend, she decided she could not take care of him and left.
now that his care is on me, my dad insists i am meddling in his business.
i know the thought of moving across the country to be closer to me and other family will overwhelm him, but i also know that this is the best for him.
we are setting up home health aide so i know that he would be safe for the time being, but im also trying to mitigate having to fly home just to get back on a plane and fly back here.
i am so nervous ill lose my job over the constant back and forth.

context: my dad lives across country with his girlfriend. we noticed something was off about a year and a half ago. he stopped taking care of himself i.e. showering, brushing his teeth, he stopped eating, didnt pay his bills etc. he started drinking way more than he used to and basically stop leaving the house. with this, he began showing signs of memory loss which was a red flag for dementia due to my familys history (two of his sisters are in assisted living for dementia and my grandmother died of alzheimers). he refused to go to the doctor, but i flew out to see him this weekend and forced him to go. the doctors have diagnosed him with severe depression and possible dementia. when this it was explained to his girlfriend, she decided she could not take care of him and left. now that his care is on me, my dad insists i am meddling in his business. i know the thought of moving across the country to be closer to me and other family will overwhelm him, but i also know that this is the best for him. at what point do you make the decisions for them? i have such anxiety about leaving him here to live on his own, but i also know that he is not going to come with me willingly. we are setting up home health aide so i know that he would be safe for the time being, but im also trying to mitigate having to fly home just to get back on a plane and fly back here. he has literally no friends or family where he currently is. it was just his girlfriends friends and family. i feel very selfish, but im sick of living on edge and not knowing what the next steps are. i am so nervous ill lose my job over the constant back and forth.

context: i'm a 28f living at home with both my parents (78m, 74f) and my sister 32f. about three years ago my mom was diagnosed with fronto-temporal dementia and right now seems to be in pretty advanced stages. she needs help with almost every task and cannot be left alone but it seems that putting her in a facility seems kind of far down the line.  i moved home a couple months before covid hit, thinking that it was going to be temporary. then i quickly saw how much help my mom needed which has increased in the \~15 months that have since passed.  in my household, i am the only one working. my sister is unemployed (and not looking for a job) and my parents are both retired. i'm a teacher and have been in the classroom with students in person this whole school year and it has been a lot weighing on me to have this stressful job (also my first year as a teacher) and then come home to my family. i feel guilty for feeling this way but i just wish my life were different and that i could move out without feeling guilty. i love my mom so much and i love caring for her in the ways that i can because she has done so much for me and i feel like its all coming full circle now. but i feel stuck at home. i want to live with my friends and have my own space and have my own schedule and eat what i want for dinner and basically just have the independence back that i had before. i know things are obviously different now and i don't want to abandon my family. i know if i left it would be a lot harder on my dad but sometimes it feels like i just can't take any of it anymore. things with my mom are certainly extremely difficult but the hardest part of all of this is that its a package deal living with my dad and sister.  has anyone else had to face this decision? a friend just asked me if i wanted to move in with her and i already said no last year in order to stay home. i just don't know how i feel about this and i want to make the right decision. i would still live close to home (prob no further than 20min by car) and could visit and come to help often. but i wouldn't be around for when she needs things in the middle of the night etc.

qas.question: are other people afraid of this?

answers.text: pros to assisted living:   there is a lot of pressure from the community health nurse to jump on it when availability happens.
the wait time is pretty significant.
if we lose our window, we might have to wait a long time.
better meals than what he's getting now.
the assisted living place isn't what his mother had.
whenever we take my dad out of the house, he's like a child lost in the woods.
the community health nurse says that it's simply the comfort of the routine that enables his normalcy, and it's only masking the actual deterioration.
if we move him now, he'll get into the "good" wing, where the residents have more independence and are cognitively alright.
no roommates.
you can't just "pop in".
we'll need to schedule around waiting hours.
he hates social activities.

when younger he hated boarding school, hated camp, hated church socializing, hated even the implication that he should have to talk to people (especially in his generation, who mocked him for his stutter).

context: whenever we take my dad out of the house, he's like a child lost in the woods. when he's at home, it's almost like he's totally normal, only with decreased mobility. the community health nurse says that it's simply the comfort of the routine that enables his normalcy, and it's only masking the actual deterioration. but i think, even that mask is valid. dad has never been more like dad, when he's home. when we take him outside, i'm always a little shocked by his inability to function. i do worry about his physical health, but i'm also equally concerned about his cognitive health, and i 90% believe that his cognition will plummet, not decline, when we remove him from the house. but am i biased? am i deluding myself? are other people afraid of this? pros to assisted living:   there is a lot of pressure from the community health nurse to jump on it when availability happens. the wait time is pretty significant. if we lose our window, we might have to wait a long time.   if we move him now, he'll get into the "good" wing, where the residents have more independence and are cognitively alright. if we wait to move him when we feel we have no choice (i.e. significantly declined) he'll have to go into the wing where the doors are locked and the residents are in decline, but there would be more one on one attention.   he is at risk of falling. mitigate that risk by having him around people more or less 24/7.   better meals than what he's getting now.   the assisted living place isn't what his mother had. no roommates. condo-style.   cons  visiting hours. you can't just "pop in". we'll need to schedule around waiting hours. he hates people. he hates socializing. he hates social activities. when younger he hated boarding school, hated camp, hated church socializing, hated even the implication that he should have to talk to people (especially in his generation, who mocked him for his stutter). the fact that taking him out of his comfortable place where he's cognitively okay may spur on a significant cognitive decline, therefore negating most of the pros above.

answers.text: warning: long post ahead!
he passed away this past may.
i'm struggling so much with his loss, the grief, and having the center of my world completely taken away.
because of covid, we didn't even have a proper burial.
warning: long post ahead!
health appointments, in-home healthcare, feeding, bathing, bathroom, dressing, and through all of the really scary breathing episodes and hard conversations about death...  we handled it together.
after his passing, my family and i were evicted from our home, homeless for a month so had to stay in a hotel and our savings dwindled to nothing, and finally moved into a small townhome.
i'm struggling so much with his loss, the grief, and having the center of my world completely taken away.
because of covid, we didn't even have a proper burial.
i know this is incredibly emotional and probably self-pitying, and it's really not meant to be that way, but i wanted to share where i am and see if others can relate?

context: warning: long post ahead! i (27f) have helped take care of my granddad for the past 10 years of my life.  i had my family with me to provide the care, so i didn't have to struggle alone and we coordinated over the years.  as time passed, my granddad's health required more care.  health appointments, in-home healthcare, feeding, bathing, bathroom, dressing, and through all of the really scary breathing episodes and hard conversations about death...  we handled it together.  i loved him so much.   he passed away this past may.   after his passing, my family and i were evicted from our home, homeless for a month so had to stay in a hotel and our savings dwindled to nothing, and finally moved into a small townhome.  holidays came, new jobs, and court cases followed (spoiler: we lost; lesson: don't get involved with shady landlords).  things have been far from easy, but definitely not as hard as they could have been. so this is all to say: i'm in a very different place than most of my peers now.  i mean, i still live at home, my credit is shot, my experiences are so vastly different than others my age, and emotionally...  i'm just so done.   i'm now in a place where i can evaluate what i want to do with the rest of my life without having to take someone else's care into account and i don't know what to do. i'm struggling so much with his loss, the grief, and having the center of my world completely taken away.  it's like my skeleton is gone and i'm just a giant puddle of what used to be me.  i don't know myself outside of his care.   i didn't even have time to process his loss and it's hitting me now wave after wave and i can't catch my breath.  because of covid, we didn't even have a proper burial.  i feel so lost and just don't know how to proceed to pick up my life and make some kind of progress.   i know this is incredibly emotional and probably self-pitying, and it's really not meant to be that way, but i wanted to share where i am and see if others can relate?  do you have advice?

context: do you have any advice for a new caregiver? i have to get all of this off my chest.  a couple weeks ago, grandma, who was living in an assisted living place, decided she was going to quit dialysis (which would cause a painless death within 14 days). she said her life wasnt worth living in a care facility, but she didnt want to burden her family with caring for her. we had a meeting, in which her 4 children and i (her grandchild), told her how much she meant to us, and that wed like to try making her life better. so instead of quitting dialysis, it was decided she would move in with me. why me? well i live the closest to where all her doctors are. she has 4 retired children, and somehow making grandmas life worth living, became my burden.  i naively thought this would be easy. i just had to cook for her, help her shower, and drive her to and from dialysis three times a week. im a freelancer, so ive been working while she naps. but i hate my new life so much.  its so draining. my complaints are so petty. but this woman who used to be the dependable matriarch of our family now calls me over ever time she needs a tiny little thing. shell ask for a tissue, which is just barely out of arms reach for her. so i stand up, walk over to her, move the tissue box a little closer, and shell say, i just needed one. ok.... then i sit back down, and shell say, i need my chapstick too. so i get up and go find that for her. as im handing it to her, she says, while youre up, could you dump this tea and make me a latte? of course i can, thats easy but why do i feel so bitter as i walk to the sink. i make her a latte (more peppermint than white chocolate, she explains). i hand it to her, and without fail she asks me, did you stir this? oh my god. why does she ask me that every time?? yes grandma, i stirred it. cooking is a whole other hassle because she has so many dietary restrictions, and she turns up her nose at anything with spices. no cumin, basil, paprika, and definitely no pepper. no onions, garlic, or bell peppers. ive basically been rotating through macaroni, pizza, and pasta for dinner.  at night, its the worst. for example yesterday she told me, after you finish working, come help me shower and then ill go to bed. good deal. but after i finished working, i went to her and she said, i didnt know youd be done so quickly. ill shower in half an hour. its 9pm at this point, but ok, i guess i can wait half an hour.... half and hour later, i come back and help her shower. instead of coming straight to bed like i expected, she said, im going to the couch to let me hair dry. ....... fine..... so she turns on ncis. i come back half an hour later. its past 10:30 now. i tell her im getting ready for bed, and she says, wheres my dessert? she wants a cinnamon roll, a whole one. i bring her one and she says, i want you to cut this into pieces for me. im pulling my hair at this point. i cut it up into little bite sized pieces and go downstairs to brush my teeth. i come back up and shes in the middle of a new episode of ncis. i tell her i need to go to bed. and she sighs and says, after this episode. so i come back as soon as the episode is over, and she has finally taken a bite of her cinnamon roll. she says, if i knew you were coming back, i would have eaten this faster. i ask her, does that mean you dont need my help getting to bed? and she sounds frustrated and says, i might fall, but i dont know when i will. so i need you nearby.  i ask her if shes done with her dessert and she says, fine, take it. its midnight at this point. then for some inexplicable reason, she opens her laptop up! gah! i tell her im going to bed and i leave. 15 minutes later i hear her calling me from her bed. i get out of bed and go to her and she says, turn off the bedroom light for me. and bring me my cell phone in case i need to call you. but dont turn the hallway light off this time! i go back to bed, its past midnight, but my head is so full of negative thoughts and emotions, i cant even fall asleep.  is this my new life? i hate it so much. i hate it. i resent my grandma. i used to respect her, and now i borderline despise her. but what choice do i have? if i tell her that im feeling burdened, shell quit dialysis and die. for what?? because i was tired of making her lattes and cutting up her food?  i keep telling myself that im just going through and adjustment period and the strong negative emotions will fade with time. but so far they seem to be getting worse.  i heard her talking on the phone yesterday with her friend. grandma told her friend that i was one of her favorites, and that i spoil her, and that shes really happy that she left the care facility. so at least my sacrifice isnt in vain.... but does she realize how difficult shes being?

context: do you have any advice for a new caregiver? i have to get all of this off my chest.  a couple weeks ago, grandma, who was living in an assisted living place, decided she was going to quit dialysis (which would cause a painless death within 14 days). she said her life wasnt worth living in a care facility, but she didnt want to burden her family with caring for her. we had a meeting, in which her 4 children and i (her grandchild), told her how much she meant to us, and that wed like to try making her life better. so instead of quitting dialysis, it was decided she would move in with me. why me? well i live the closest to where all her doctors are. she has 4 retired children, and somehow making grandmas life worth living, became my burden.  i naively thought this would be easy. i just had to cook for her, help her shower, and drive her to and from dialysis three times a week. im a freelancer, so ive been working while she naps. but i hate my new life so much.  its so draining. my complaints are so petty. but this woman who used to be the dependable matriarch of our family now calls me over ever time she needs a tiny little thing. shell ask for a tissue, which is just barely out of arms reach for her. so i stand up, walk over to her, move the tissue box a little closer, and shell say, i just needed one. ok.... then i sit back down, and shell say, i need my chapstick too. so i get up and go find that for her. as im handing it to her, she says, while youre up, could you dump this tea and make me a latte? of course i can, thats easy but why do i feel so bitter as i walk to the sink. i make her a latte (more peppermint than white chocolate, she explains). i hand it to her, and without fail she asks me, did you stir this? oh my god. why does she ask me that every time?? yes grandma, i stirred it. cooking is a whole other hassle because she has so many dietary restrictions, and she turns up her nose at anything with spices. no cumin, basil, paprika, and definitely no pepper. no onions, garlic, or bell peppers. ive basically been rotating through macaroni, pizza, and pasta for dinner.  at night, its the worst. for example yesterday she told me, after you finish working, come help me shower and then ill go to bed. good deal. but after i finished working, i went to her and she said, i didnt know youd be done so quickly. ill shower in half an hour. its 9pm at this point, but ok, i guess i can wait half an hour.... half and hour later, i come back and help her shower. instead of coming straight to bed like i expected, she said, im going to the couch to let me hair dry. ....... fine..... so she turns on ncis. i come back half an hour later. its past 10:30 now. i tell her im getting ready for bed, and she says, wheres my dessert? she wants a cinnamon roll, a whole one. i bring her one and she says, i want you to cut this into pieces for me. im pulling my hair at this point. i cut it up into little bite sized pieces and go downstairs to brush my teeth. i come back up and shes in the middle of a new episode of ncis. i tell her i need to go to bed. and she sighs and says, after this episode. so i come back as soon as the episode is over, and she has finally taken a bite of her cinnamon roll. she says, if i knew you were coming back, i would have eaten this faster. i ask her, does that mean you dont need my help getting to bed? and she sounds frustrated and says, i might fall, but i dont know when i will. so i need you nearby.  i ask her if shes done with her dessert and she says, fine, take it. its midnight at this point. then for some inexplicable reason, she opens her laptop up! gah! i tell her im going to bed and i leave. 15 minutes later i hear her calling me from her bed. i get out of bed and go to her and she says, turn off the bedroom light for me. and bring me my cell phone in case i need to call you. but dont turn the hallway light off this time! i go back to bed, its past midnight, but my head is so full of negative thoughts and emotions, i cant even fall asleep.  is this my new life? i hate it so much. i hate it. i resent my grandma. i used to respect her, and now i borderline despise her. but what choice do i have? if i tell her that im feeling burdened, shell quit dialysis and die. for what?? because i was tired of making her lattes and cutting up her food?  i keep telling myself that im just going through and adjustment period and the strong negative emotions will fade with time. but so far they seem to be getting worse.  i heard her talking on the phone yesterday with her friend. grandma told her friend that i was one of her favorites, and that i spoil her, and that shes really happy that she left the care facility. so at least my sacrifice isnt in vain.... but does she realize how difficult shes being?

of course i can, thats easy but why do i feel so bitter as i walk to the sink. i make her a latte (more peppermint than white chocolate, she explains). i hand it to her, and without fail she asks me, did you stir this? oh my god. why does she ask me that every time?? yes grandma, i stirred it. cooking is a whole other hassle because she has so many dietary restrictions, and she turns up her nose at anything with spices. no cumin, basil, paprika, and definitely no pepper. no onions, garlic, or bell peppers. ive basically been rotating through macaroni, pizza, and pasta for dinner.  at night, its the worst. for example yesterday she told me, after you finish working, come help me shower and then ill go to bed. good deal. but after i finished working, i went to her and she said, i didnt know youd be done so quickly. ill shower in half an hour. its 9pm at this point, but ok, i guess i can wait half an hour.... half and hour later, i come back and help her shower. instead of coming straight to bed like i expected, she said, im going to the couch to let me hair dry. ....... fine..... so she turns on ncis. i come back half an hour later. its past 10:30 now. i tell her im getting ready for bed, and she says, wheres my dessert? she wants a cinnamon roll, a whole one. i bring her one and she says, i want you to cut this into pieces for me. im pulling my hair at this point. i cut it up into little bite sized pieces and go downstairs to brush my teeth. i come back up and shes in the middle of a new episode of ncis. i tell her i need to go to bed. and she sighs and says, after this episode. so i come back as soon as the episode is over, and she has finally taken a bite of her cinnamon roll. she says, if i knew you were coming back, i would have eaten this faster. i ask her, does that mean you dont need my help getting to bed? and she sounds frustrated and says, i might fall, but i dont know when i will. so i need you nearby.  i ask her if shes done with her dessert and she says, fine, take it. its midnight at this point. then for some inexplicable reason, she opens her laptop up! gah! i tell her im going to bed and i leave. 15 minutes later i hear her calling me from her bed. i get out of bed and go to her and she says, turn off the bedroom light for me. and bring me my cell phone in case i need to call you. but dont turn the hallway light off this time! i go back to bed, its past midnight, but my head is so full of negative thoughts and emotions, i cant even fall asleep.  is this my new life? i hate it so much. i hate it. i resent my grandma. i used to respect her, and now i borderline despise her. but what choice do i have? if i tell her that im feeling burdened, shell quit dialysis and die. for what?? because i was tired of making her lattes and cutting up her food?  i keep telling myself that im just going through and adjustment period and the strong negative emotions will fade with time. but so far they seem to be getting worse.  i heard her talking on the phone yesterday with her friend. grandma told her friend that i was one of her favorites, and that i spoil her, and that shes really happy that she left the care facility. so at least my sacrifice isnt in vain.... but does she realize how difficult shes being?

qas.question: because i was tired of making her lattes and cutting up her food?

qas.question: anyone else feels this way or has tips to deal with a traumatic loss like this?

answers.text: he has been gone for so long but its like i was never able to grief.
my grandpa had lewy body dementia.
its been 7 years since he has died now.
it was distressing seeing him get progressively worse, have hallucinations and become extremely paranoid.
it was also hard seeing him physically change until he was unrecognizable.

context: i feel like caring for my grandpa with lewy body dementia has been traumatic for me. i have nightmares of him chasing me and poping out of nowhere. is this normal?? i feel like i shouldve moved on. my grandpa had lewy body dementia. its been 7 years since he has died now.  my grandpa started being ill when i was 10 and slowly got worse until he died when i was 15. we didnt live with him but came to visit often. it was distressing seeing him get progressively worse, have hallucinations and become extremely paranoid. he very quickly forgot who i was and what time-period we were in. he was also awful to my grandmother who looked after him, he would be extremely rude and at times violent. it was also hard seeing him physically change until he was unrecognizable. the worse thing was probably seeing what it did to my mum, who is extremely closed off emotionally but was clearly holding back how depressed she was during that time.  he has been gone for so long but its like i was never able to grief. i respected him so much before it all started. now i feel so guilty that most of my memories with him make me hate him. and im so scared my mum will have the same illness as she ages. last night was the first time my grandpa was in my dream and looked completely powerless and didnt chase after me or anything, as i was explaining to a child what was going on with him.  anyone else feels this way or has tips to deal with a traumatic loss like this?

qas.question: other photos?

answers.text: a group photo of a wedding i had never known there were photos of.
cut out every individual until the photo was just slivers in a plastic bag.
cut the guests out on either side.
photo of my grandfather holding my aunt in the hospital.
photo of me being held by my great grandfather.
sliced his head right off.
every photo of them standing in front of a view is haphazardly cut into a sliver of just the person standing.
my grandfather at his office at ibm in nyc.
cut out his office and desk.
portraits?
there are copies of a couple of the photos that she didnt have time to get to.
this is so painful to experience as a family member.
cut out the baby.
sliced his head right off.
every photo of them standing in front of a view is haphazardly cut into a sliver of just the person standing.
there are copies of a couple of the photos that she didnt have time to get to.
i just dont understand it, sometimes.
i simply cannot comprehend the reasoning.
this is so painful to experience as a family member.
even after theyre not in your care anymore.
but its almost impossible to know what she is going through.
i cannot imagine.
i think i might tell a little more about her story in another post.
but right now i have memories and a mind to mourn.

context: a group photo of a wedding i had never known there were photos of. cut out every individual until the photo was just slivers in a plastic bag.  the bride walking down the isle. cut the guests out on either side. photo of my grandfather holding my aunt in the hospital. cut out the baby. photo of me being held by my great grandfather. sliced his head right off. the only photographs of my grandparents on their 1984 american road trip. every photo of them standing in front of a view is haphazardly cut into a sliver of just the person standing. my grandfather at his office at ibm in nyc. cut out his office and desk. other photos? cropped the top off. portraits? cropped the sides. my brothers graduation. cut out my brother, with my moms arms around him. there are copies of a couple of the photos that she didnt have time to get to. but the damage is done. i just dont understand it, sometimes. i simply cannot comprehend the reasoning. this must have happened before we took away sharp objects. this is so painful to experience as a family member. even after theyre not in your care anymore. but its almost impossible to know what she is going through. i cannot imagine. i think i might tell a little more about her story in another post. but right now i have memories and a mind to mourn.

qas.question: i've read about sundowning, but isn't that usually occurring in people who have advanced cases of dementia/alzheimers?

answers.text: starting around a year ago, she began to have issues with memory/cognition/anxiety that usually begins roughly around 4 pm each night, but is gone by morning.
she is has been evaluated (always in the morning) and nobody has picked up on anything.
my parents believe it is a medication thing, but i'm unsure.
my 65-year-old mother has been severely mentally ill (schizophrenia, bi-polar, depression, anxiety,  etc) since the 70s.
she is medicated and receiving therapy.
she also has a history of alcohol abuse.
the next morning/day she is back to normal.
she is has been evaluated (always in the morning) and nobody has picked up on anything.

context: my 65-year-old mother has been severely mentally ill (schizophrenia, bi-polar, depression, anxiety,  etc) since the 70s. she is medicated and receiving therapy. she also has a history of alcohol abuse.  starting around a year ago, she began to have issues with memory/cognition/anxiety that usually begins roughly around 4 pm each night, but is gone by morning. the next morning/day she is back to normal.  since the pandemic began, she spends most of her day watching youtube, netflix, etc.  she is has been evaluated (always in the morning) and nobody has picked up on anything.  i've read about sundowning, but isn't that usually occurring in people who have advanced cases of dementia/alzheimers? my parents believe it is a medication thing, but i'm unsure.

qas.question: is there any advice that you can give me as we head down this road?

answers.text: found this subreddit recently and started lurking until today where i felt motivated to post.
i (23m) live with my mom (60) and grandma (82) who has been diagnosed with dementia (possibly lewy body).

my grandma although clearly cognitively unwell, still remembers that she hates my mom and treats her terribly; whether its damning her to live alone or telling her to eat shit, saying were poisoning her, or talking badly of her to anyone who stays to watch her for a couple hours while we run errands.

my mom is so tired from having to work and then take care of her abusive mother, and i cant help as much as i can being that i am in college and dealing with classes, maintaining my job (i run a small buisness online from home) and having to be available for my father who is declining with alzheimers and his care/doctors appointments.
what do i even do?
has anyone else gone through something like this?
throwaway account.
what do i even do?
has anyone else gone through something like this?
i feel terrible knowing my mom is suffering and i cannot help as much as i should be.

neither of us even mind helping her get up and go to the bathroom, making her food (that she refuses to eat), putting her to bed; but when she calls out every 5 minutes to get you to do something and then starts the verbal abuse, its unbearable.
luckily i dont get the abuse but watching my mother get it is almost worse; i rather be at the recieving end of it.
my mom is so depressed as her life is passing by her and i dont know what to do.
my dad had a tbi in december of 2018 that left him unable to drive, work, and do most things for himself.
im planning on moving out soon as i am 22 so she really needs to step it up as a caregiver.
he used to be a handyman and thats all that interests him now.
with his lack of problem solving i really think he shouldnt be using power tools at all he is going to seriously hurt himself.
as far as food he wont cook for himself and my mom doesnt meal prep anything for him.
she already told me she doesnt love him anymore.
i am completely torn.
but from the outside he seems fine to other people.
initially he was attending therapies to help but he wasnt doing the work on his own time without my moms help so she stopped taking him (that seems unfair to me).
im planning on moving out soon as i am 22 so she really needs to step it up as a caregiver.
he used to be a handyman and thats all that interests him now.
he constantly cuts himself and has already started a fire!
the thing about my mom is that she has always been self centered and never supportive so its tough trying to tell her shes doing something wrong.
i am completely torn.
most psychiatric conditions have been discarded by now (bp, psychotic depression) and it seems like he might have ftd or another form of dementia.
i am from a developing country and i live abroad with my husband.
my dad is 59 years old, an avid cyclist, and extremely smart.
luckily he only broke his collarbone and got surgery for it.
over the last few weeks, the doctors have started a new anti-psychotic and multiple anti-depressants.
most psychiatric conditions have been discarded by now (bp, psychotic depression) and it seems like he might have ftd or another form of dementia.
my mother has been having memory issues for a while but we dismissed it as her being too much of a social drinker.
she was positive that my husband and i were closely related and only me saying that we had had genetic testing while pursuing infertility treatments could allay her fears.
i just feel a little lost, like i lost my father and then immediately started to lose my mother and i dont know what to do.
my mother has been having memory issues for a while but we dismissed it as her being too much of a social drinker.
in the last 6 months, things have gotten really bad.

answers.text: it's not really any of my business but people keep bringing it to my attention.
he keeps to himself but i've noticed he's deteriorated over the years and has had a few hospital admissions.
he lives alone and has carers that visit 4 times a day.
he was just rummaging around in some rubbish in his garden with no clothes on, his garden is not private, it has a low wall and school children walk on the path right behind it.
i'm worried that it's undignified for him and possibly upsetting to children who have and might witness it.
it's not really any of my business but people keep bringing it to my attention.

i'm a soon to be registered nurse and i work on an elderly care ward so i'm very used to taking care of people that present like this, but he is my neighbour who i don't have a relationship with, i don't want to overstep any boundaries.

context: an elderly gentleman lives next door, i'm fairly sure he has dementia but i don't know of any official diagnosis, though his behaviour points to this. he keeps to himself but i've noticed he's deteriorated over the years and has had a few hospital admissions. he lives alone and has carers that visit 4 times a day. anyway, the odd behaviour...he's been seen naked in the garden a few times that i know of, i've had a few people knock on my door to tell me. he was just rummaging around in some rubbish in his garden with no clothes on, his garden is not private, it has a low wall and school children walk on the path right behind it. i'm worried that it's undignified for him and possibly upsetting to children who have and might witness it.  it's not really any of my business but people keep bringing it to my attention. my husband mentioned it to his carers once, should i bring it up to them again? i'm a soon to be registered nurse and i work on an elderly care ward so i'm very used to taking care of people that present like this, but he is my neighbour who i don't have a relationship with, i don't want to overstep any boundaries.

qas.question: what sort of questions should we ask in order to get the full picture and to help my grandpa understand it a little bit better?

answers.text: my grandmother, whose (likely) dementia has been worsening at an increased pace for the last two or so years, but she was always able to talk herself out of a diagnosis when at the doctors, and my grandfather was in denial about all of it.
she would call my dad at all hours of the day and night to tell him there is a man in their house, she didnt feel safe, and wanted to go home.
she can barely get around their small home on a good day.
she hasnt driven anywhere in 7 or so years.
it is 30 and freezing rain here today, but she decided to go for a walk.
thanks

context: my grandmother, whose (likely) dementia has been worsening at an increased pace for the last two or so years, but she was always able to talk herself out of a diagnosis when at the doctors, and my grandfather was in denial about all of it. she now hasnt been to a doctor in over a year for any reason because she doesnt like to leave the house.  lately she has been alternating between confusing my grandpa for her abusive step father or not know who he is entirely. she would call my dad at all hours of the day and night to tell him there is a man in their house, she didnt feel safe, and wanted to go home. my dad is always able to calm her down, so although stressful for all involved, my grandpa was still not convinced she needed medical intervention. she oftentimes thinks people are breaking into the house, someone is stealing their money, or spying on them.  my grandma walks hunched over with a cane. she can barely get around their small home on a good day. she hasnt driven anywhere in 7 or so years. my grandpa has breathing problems and tires out easily, and often naps.  today, for the first time, my grandma left the house while he was sleeping. it is 30 and freezing rain here today, but she decided to go for a walk. a neighbor saw her down the street and took her back home. grandpa called my dad, who came over and had a hard talk about taking her to the doctor.  so, on monday they will call and make an appointment with her gp. what sort of questions should we ask in order to get the full picture and to help my grandpa understand it a little bit better? i know this isnt going to be easy on either of them, but we want to try to make things as painless as possible.  thanks
